dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acres of gray steel desk, gray steel filing cabinets, and steel-gray faces under indirect light.  One wall is lined with glass-enclosed cubicles for the supervisory personne It is all very neat, antiseptic, impersonal.  The only hu tough is supplied by a bank of IBM machines, clacking awa cheerfully in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work on the nineteenth floor -- Ordinary Policy Department - Premium Accounting Division - Section W -- desk number 861.

dialogues.speaker: DESK 861
dialogues.text: Like every other desk, it has a small name plate attached the side.  This one reads C.C. BAXTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is C.C. Baxter - C. for Calvin, C. for Clifford -- however, most people call me Bud. I've been with Consolidated Life for three years and ten months.  I started in the branch office in Cincinnati, then transferred to New York.  My take-home pay is $94.70 a week, and there are the usual fringe benefits. BAXTER is about thirty, serious, hard-working, unobtrusiv He wears a Brooks Brothers type suit, which he bought somewhere on Seventh Avenue, upstairs.  There is a stack perforated premium cards in front of him, and he is total them on the computing machine.  He looks off.

dialogues.speaker: ELECTRIC WALL CLOCK
dialogues.text: It shows 5:19.  With a click, the minute hand jumps to 5: and a piercing bell goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hours in our department are 8:50 to 5:20 --

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Instantly all work stops.  Papers are being put away, typewriters and computing machines are covered, and every starts clearing out.  Within ten seconds, the place is empty -- except for Bud Baxter, still bent over his work, marooned in a sea of abandoned desks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- they're staggered by floors, so that sixteen elevators can handle the 31,259 employees without a serious traffic jam.  As for myself, I very often stay on at the office and work for an extra hour or two -- especially when the weather is bad.  It's not that I'm overly ambitious -- it's just a way of killing time, until it's all right for me to go home. You see, I have this little problem with my apartment --

dialogues.speaker: STREET IN THE WEST SIXTIES
dialogues.text: Bud, wearing a weather-beaten Ivy League raincoat and a narrow-brimmed brown hat, comes walking slowly down the street skirting the puddles on the sidewalk.  He stops in front of a converted brownstone, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in the West Sixties - just half a block from Central Park.  My rent is $84 a month.  It used to be eighty until last July when Mrs. Lieberman, the landlady, put in a second-hand air conditioning unit. The windows on the second floor are lit, but the shades a drawn.  From inside drifts the sound of cha cha music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a real nice apartment - nothing fancy -- but kind of cozy -- just right for a bachelor. The only problem is - I can't always get in when I want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What used to be the upstairs parlor of a one-family house the early 1900's has been chopped up into living room, bedroom, bathroom and kitchen.  The wallpaper is faded, t carpets are threadbare, and the upholstered furniture cou stand shampooing.  There are lots of books, a record play stacks of records, a television set (21 inches and 24 payments), unframed prints from the Museum of Modern Art (Picasso, Braque, Klee) tacked up on the walls. Only one lamp is lit, for mood, and a cha cha record is spinning around on the phonograph.  On the coffee table i front of the couch are a couple of cocktail glasses, a pitcher with some martini dregs, an almost empty bottle o vodka, a soup bowl with a few melting ice cubes at the bottom, some potato chips, an ashtray filled with cigar stubs and lipstick-stained cigarette butts, and a woman's handbag. MR. KIRKEBY, a dapper, middle-aged man, stands in front o the mirror above the fake fireplace, buttoning up his ves He does not notice that the buttons are out of alignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sylvia.  It's getting late. SYLVIA, a first baseman of a dame, redheaded and saftig, comes cha cha-ing into the room, trying to fasten a neckl as she hums along with the music.  She dances amorously u to Kirkeby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Sylvia.  We got to get out of here. He helps her with the necklace, then turns off the phonog

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the panic?  I'm going to have another martooni. She crosses to the coffee table, starts to pour the remna of the vodka into the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Sylvia!  It's a quarter to nine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping slivers of ice into the pitcher)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you can't wait to get me up here, and now -- rush, rush, rush! Makes a person feel cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia -- sweetie -- it's not that -- but I promised the guy I'd be out of here by eight o'clock, positively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring martini)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What guy?  Whose apartment is this, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference?  Some schnook that works in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is pacing back and forth, throwing an occasional glan at the lit windows of his apartment.  A middle-aged woman with a dog on a leash approaches along the sidewalk. She is MRS. LIEBERMAN, the dog is a Scottie, and they are both wearing raincoats.  Seeing them, Bud leans casually against the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs. Lieberman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some weather we're having.  Must be from all the meshugass at Cape Canaveral. (she is half-way up the steps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You locked out of your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  Just waiting for a friend. Good night, Mrs. Lieberman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Baxter. She and the Scottie disappear into the house.  Bud resume pacing, his eyes on the apartment windows.  Suddenly he stops -- the lights have gone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirkeby, in coat and hat, stands in the open doorway of t darkened apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- come on, Sylvia! Sylvia comes cha cha-ing out, wearing an imitation Persia lamb coat, her hat askew on her head, bag, gloves, and an umbrella in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some setup you got here.  A real, honest-to-goodness love nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssssh. He locks the door, slips the key under the doormat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still cha cha-ing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're one button off, Mr. Kirkeby. She points to his exposed vest.  Kirkeby looks down, sees that the buttons are out of line.  He starts to rebutton them as they move down the narrow, dimly-lit stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to watch those things. Wives are getting smarter all the time.  Take Mr. Bernheim -- in the Claims Department -- came home one night with lipstick on his shirt -- told his wife he had a shrimp cocktail for lunch -- so she took it out to the lab and had it analyzed -- so now she has the house in Great Neck and the children and the new Jaguar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever stop talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, standing on the sidewalk, sees the front door start open.  He moves quickly into the areaway, almost bumping into the ashcans, stands in the shadow of the stoop with back turned discreetly toward Kirkeby and Sylvia as they come down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you -- with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does she live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and seventy-ninth street -- the Bronx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- I'll take you to the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell you will.  You'll buy me a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do all you dames have to live in the Bronx?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you bring other girls up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not.  I'm a happily married man. They move down the street.  Bud appears from the areaway, glances after them, then mounts the steps, goes through t front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are eight mailboxes.  Bud opens his, takes out a magazine in a paper wrapper and a few letters, proceeds u the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, glancing through his mail, comes up to the door of h apartment.  As he bends down to lift the doormat, the doo of the rear apartment opens and MRS. DREYFUSS, a jovial well-fed middle-aged woman, puts out a receptacle full of old papers and empty cans.  Bud looks around from his ben position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Hello there, Mrs. Dreyfuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to have dropped my key. (faking a little search)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- here it is. He slides it out from under the mat, straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a racket I heard in your place -- maybe you had burglars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't have to worry about that -- nothing in there that anybody would want to steal... (unlocking door quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mrs. Dreyfuss. He ducks into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud snaps on the lights, drops the mail and the key on a small table, looks around with distaste at the mess his visitors have left behind.  He sniffs the stale air, cros to the window, pulls up the shade, opens it wide.  Now he takes off his hat and raincoat, gathers up the remains of the cocktail party from the coffee table.  Loaded down wi glasses, pitcher, empty vodka bottle, ice bowl and potato chips, he starts toward the kitchen. The doorbell rings.  Bud stops, undecided what to do with the stuff in his hands, then crosses to the hall door, barely manages to get it open.  Mr. Kirkeby barges in pas him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little lady forgot her galoshes. He scours the room for the missing galoshes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kirkeby, I don't like to complain -- but you were supposed to be out of here by eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Buddy-boy, I know.  But those things don't always run on schedule -- like a Greyhound bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind in the summer -- but on a rainy night -- and I haven't had any dinner yet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure.  Look, kid -- I put in a good word for you with Sheldrake, in Personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  We were discussing our department -- manpower-wise -- and promotion-wise -- (finds the galoshes behind a chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I told him what a bright boy you were.  They're always on the lookout for young executives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Kirkeby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting toward door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on your way up, Buddy-boy. And you're practically out of liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Mr. Eichelberger -- in the Mortgage Loan Department -- last night he had a little Halloween party here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, lay in some vodka and some vermouth -- and put my name on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Kirkeby.  You still owe me for the last two bottles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay you on Friday. (in the open doorwaY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whatever happened to those little cheese crackers you used to have around? He exits, shutting the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a mental note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheese crackers. He carries his load into the kitchen. The kitchen is minute and cluttered.  On the drainboard a an empty vermouth bottle, some ice-cube trays, a jar with one olive in it, and a crumpled potato-chip bag. Bud comes in, dumps his load on the drainboard, opens the old-fashioned refrigerator.  He takes out a frozen chicke dinner, turns the oven on, lights it with a match, rips t protective paper off the aluminum tray and shoves it in. Now he starts to clean up the mess on the drainboard.  He rinses the cocktail glasses, is about to empty the martin pitcher into the sink, thinks better of it.  He pours the contents into a glass, plops the lone olive out of the ja scoops up the last handful of potato chips, toasts an imaginary companion, and drinks up.  Then he pulls a wastebasket from under the sink. It is brimful of liquor bottles, and Bud adds the empty vodka and vermouth bottles and the olive jar.  Picking up the heavy receptacle, he carries it through the living ro toward the hall door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of Bud's apartment opens, and Bud comes out with the wastebasket full of empty bottles.  Just then, DR. DA DREYFUSS, whose wife we met earlier, comes trudging up th stairs.  He is a tall, heavy-set man of fifty, with a bus mustache, wearing a bulky overcoat and carrying an aged medical bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Doc.  Had a late call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Some clown at Schrafft's 57th Street ate a club sandwich, and forgot to take out the toothpick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (sets down wastebasket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating bottles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Baxter -- the way you're belting that stuff, you must have a pair of cast-iron kidneys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's not me.  It's just that once in a while, I have some people in for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, you must be an iron man all around. From what I hear through the walls, you got something going for you every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if it gets noisy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes,  there's a twi-night double-header. (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nebbish like you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Well -- see you, Doc. (starts to back through door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Baxter -- I'm doing some research at the Columbia Medical Center -- and I wonder if you could do us a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you make out your will -- and the way you're going, you should -- would you mind leaving your body to the University?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My body?  I'm afraid you guys would be disappointed.  Good night, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, kid. He starts into the rear apartment as Bud closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, loosening his tie, goes into the kitchen, opens the oven, turns off the gas.  He takes a coke out of the refrigerator, uncaps it, gets a knife and fork from a drawer, and using his handkerchief as a potholder, pulls hot aluminum tray out of the oven.  He carries everything out into the living room. In the living room, Bud sets his dinner down on the coffe table, settles himself on the couch.  He rears up as something stabs him, reaches under his buttocks, pulls ou hairpin.  He drops it into an ashtray, tackles his dinner Without even looking, he reaches over to the end table an presses the remote TV station-selector.  He takes a sip f the coke bottle, his eyes on the TV screen across the roo The picture on the TV set jells quickly.  Against a background of crisscrossing searchlights, a pompous annou is making his spiel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- from the world's greatest library of film classics, we proudly present -- (fanfare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greta Garbo -- John Barrymore -- Joan Crawford -- Wallace Beery -- and Lionel Barrymore in -- (fanfare)

dialogues.speaker: GRAND HOTEL
dialogues.text: There is an extended fanfare.  Bud leans forward, chewing excitedly on a chicken leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But first, a word from our sponsor. If you smoke the modern way, don't be fooled by phony filter claims -- Bud, still eating, automatically reaches for the station- selector, pushes the button. A new channel pops on.  It features a Western -- Cockamam Indians are attacking a stagecoach. That's not for Bud.  He switches to another station.  In frontier saloon, Gower Street cowboys are dismantling the furniture and each other. Bud wearily changes channels.  But he can't get away from Westerns -- on this station, the U.S. Cavalry is riding t the rescue.  Will they get there in time? Bud doesn't wait to find out.  He switches channels again and is back where he started. On the screen, once more, is the announcer standing in fr of the crisscrossing searchlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, Grand Hotel -- starring Greta Garbo, John Barrymore, Joan Crawford -- (Bud is all eyes and ears again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Wallace Beery, and Lionel Barrymore.  But first -- a word from our alternate sponsor. (unctuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends, do you have wobbly dentures -- ? That does it.  Bud turns the set off in disgust. The TV screen blacks out, except for a small pinpoint of light in the center, which gradually fades away. In the bathroom, Bud, in pajamas by now, is brushing his teeth.  From the shower rod hang three pairs of socks on stretchers.  Bud takes a vial from the medicine shelf, shakes out a sleeping pill, washes it down with a glass o water.  He turns the light off, walks into the bedroom. In the bedroom, the single bed is made, and the lamp on t night table is on.  Bud plugs in the electric blanket, tu the dial on.  Then he climbs into bed, props up the pillo behind him.  From the night table, he picks up the magazi that arrived in the mail, slides it out of the wrapper, opens it.  It's the new issue of PLAYBOY.  Bud leafs thro it till he comes to the piece de resistance of the magazi He unfolds the overleaf, glances at it casually, refolds then turns to the back of the magazine and starts to read What he is so avidly interested in is the men's fashion section.  There is a layout titled WHAT THE YOUNG EXECUTI WILL WEAR with a sub-head reading The Bowler is Back. Illustrating the article are several photographs of male models wearing various styles of bowlers. Bud is definitely in the market for a bowler, but somehow his mind starts wandering.  He turns back to the overleaf again, unfolds it, studies it, then holds the magazine up vertically to get a different perspective on the subject. By now the sleeping pill is beginning to take effect, and yawns.  He drops the magazine on the floor, kills the lig settles down to sleep.  The room is dark except for the g from the dial of the electric blanket. Three seconds.  Then the phone jangles shrilly in the liv room.  Bud stumbles groggily out of bed, and putting on h slippers, makes his way into the living room.  He switche on the light, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? -- Hello? -- yes, this is Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the night is a hearty man of about forty-five, nothing gut personality, most of it obnoxious.  His name is DOBIS Outside the booth is a blonde babe, slightly boozed, and beyond there is a suggestion of the packed, smoky joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Buddy-boy.  I'm in this bar on Sixty-first Street -- and I got to thinking about you -- and I figured I'd give you a little buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's very nice of you -- but who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dobisch -- Joe Dobisch, in Administration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping to attention)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Mr. Dobisch.  I didn't recognize your voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, Buddy-boy.  Now like I was saying, I'm in this joint on Sixty-first -- and I think I got lucky -- (glances toward blonde)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- she's a skater with the Ice Show -- (he chuckles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I thought maybe I could bring her up for a quiet drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Dobisch.  You know I like to help you guys out -- but it's sort of late -- so why don't we make it some other time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy-boy -- she won't keep that long -- not even on ice.  Listen, kid, I can't pass this up -- she looks like Marilyn Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if it is Marilyn Monroe -- I'm already in bed -- and I've taken a sleeping pill -- so I'm afraid the answer is no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling rank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Baxter -- we're making out the monthly efficiency rating -- and I'm putting you in the top ten. Now you don't want to louse yourself up, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.  But -- how can I be efficient in the office if I don't get enough sleep at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only eleven -- and I just want the place for forty-five minutes. The blonde opens the door of the phone booth, leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting lonely.  Who are you talking to, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sweet.  That's real sweet. Dobisch shuts the door in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it thirty minutes.  What do you say, Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a last stand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all out of liquor -- and there's no clean glasses -- no cheese crackers -- no nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me worry about that.  Just leave the key under the mat and clear out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone; resigned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Dobisch. He hangs up, shuffles back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you say, Mr. Dobisch -- no trouble at all, Mr. Dobisch -- be my guest -- He reappears from the bedroom, pulling his trousers on ov his pajama pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We never close at Buddy-boy's -- looks like Marilyn Monroe -- (he chuckles a la Dobisch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting on his raincoat and hat, Bud opens the hall door, takes the key from the table, shoves it under the doormat His eyes fall on the Dreyfuss apartment, and there is som concern on his face.  He picks up a pad and pencil from t table, prints something in block letters.  Tearing off th top sheet, he impales it on the spindle of the phonograph then walks out, closing the door behind him.  The note re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes out the door, in slippered feet, pants and rain over his pajamas.  As he sleep-walks down the steps, a ca pulls up in front of the house.  Bud ducks discreetly int the areaway.  Mr. Dobisch, bareheaded, emerges cautiously from the cab.  Between the fingers of his hands he is carrying four long-stemmed glasses, brimful of stingers. The blonde steps out, holding his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This the place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (to cab driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy cents. Dobisch, his hands full of stingers, turns to the blonde, indicates his pants pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the money, will you? The blonde plants the hat on top of his head, unbuttons h overcoat, reaches into his pants pocket.  As she does so, she jogs his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch those stingers! The blonde has taken out Dobisch's money clip, with about hundred dollars in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him a buck. The blonde peels a bill off, hands it to the cabbie, hang on to the rest of the roll just a second too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now put it back, honey. (she does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta girl. The cab drives off.  Dobisch and the blonde start up the steps to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure this is a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't think of a better one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding door open for him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean - barging in on your mother -- in the middle of the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (edging past her with stingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the old lady. One squawk from her, and she's out of a job. In the areaway, Bud has overheard them, and it doesn't ma him any happier.  He steps out on the sidewalk, shuffles down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde and Dobisch, his hands full of stingers, come to Bud's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the key, will you. Automatically, she reaches into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not there.  Under the mat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the mat? (picks up key)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up, open up -- we haven't got all night. The blonde unlocks the door to the apartment, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is your mother's apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Maria Ouspenskaya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sticking her head in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Ouspenskaya. Dobisch nudges her inside with his knee, kicks the door s behind him. The landing is empty for a second.  Then the door of the rear apartment opens, and Dr. Dreyfuss, in a beaten bathr sets out a couple of empty milk bottles with a note in th Suddenly, from Bud's apartment, comes a shrill female gig Dr. Dreyfuss reacts.  Then the cha cha music starts full blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to his wife, off-screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred -- he's at it again. Shaking his head, he closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, in raincoat and slippered feet, turns in off the street, plods along a path in the deserted park.  He stop at a damp bench under a lamp post, sits.  In the backgrou lights shine from the towering buildings on Central Park South. Bud huddles inside his raincoat, shivering.  He is very sleepy by now.  His eyes close and his head droops.  A gu of wind sends wet leaves swirling across the bench.  Bud doesn't stir.  He is all in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a quarter to nine of a gray November morning, and wo bound employees are piling in through the doors.  Among t is Bud, bundled up in a raincoat, hat, heavy muffler and wool gloves, and carrying a box of Kleenex.  He coughs, pulls out a tissue, wipes his dripping nose.  He has a ba cold. The lobby is an imposing, marbled affair, as befits a company which last year wrote 9.3 billion dollars worth o insurance.  There are sixteen elevators, eight of them marked LOCAL - FLOORS 1-18, and opposite them eight marke EXPRESS - FLOORS 18-37.  The starter, a uniformed Valkyri wielding a clicker, is directing the flow of traffic into the various elevators. Bud joins the crowd in front of one of the express elevat Also standing there is Mr. Kirkeby, reading the Herald- Tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Kirkeby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he just knew him vaguely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, how are you, Baxter.  They keeping you busy these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  They are indeed. (he sniffs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open, revealing the operator.  She is her middle twenties and her name is FRAN KUBELIK.  Maybe it's the way she's put together, maybe it's her face, or maybe it's just the uniform -- in any case, there is something very appealing about her.  She is also an individualist -- she wears a carnation in her lapel, whic is strictly against regulations.  As the elevator loads, greets the passengers cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattling it off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Kessel -- Morning, Miss Robinson -- Morning, Mr. Kirkeby -- Morning, Mr. Williams -- Morning, Miss Livingston -- Morning, Mr. McKellway -- Morning, Mr. Pirelli -- Morning, Mrs. Schubert -- Interspersed is an occasional "Morning, Miss Kubelik" fro the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Miss Kubelik. He takes his hat off -- he is the only one.  The express now loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working the clicker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.  Take it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shutting the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the door, please.  Blasting off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is standing right next to Fran as the packed express shoots up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do to your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was making me nervous, so I chopped it off.  Big mistake, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sort of like it. He sniffs, takes out a Kleenex, wipes his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you got a lulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I better not get too close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I never catch colds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  I was looking at some figures from the Sickness and Accident Claims Division -- do you know that the average New Yorker between the ages of twenty and fifty has two and a half colds a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes me feel just terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, to make the figures come out even -- since I have no colds a year -- some poor slob must have five colds a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. (dabs his nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have stayed in bed this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have stayed in bed last night. The elevator has slowed down, now stops.  Fran opens the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen.  Watch your step. About a third of the passengers get out, including Bud an Mr. Kirkeby.  As Kirkeby passes Fran, he slaps her behind with his folded newspaper.  Fran jumps slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all in the day's work)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And watch your hand, Mr. Kirkeby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days I'm going to shut those doors on you and -- She withdraws her hand into the sleeve of her uniform, an waves the "amputated" arm at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty next. The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirkeby turns away from the elevator, and grinning smugly falls in beside Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Kubelik -- boy!  Would I like to get her on a slow elevator to China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.  She's the best operator in the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a pretty good operator myself -- but she just won't give me a tumble -- date-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're using the wrong approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of guys around here have tried it -- all kinds of approaches -- no dice.  What is she trying to prove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be she's just a nice, respectable girl -- there are millions of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to him.  Little Lord Fauntleroy! Leaving Bud at the employees' coat-racks, Kirkeby heads toward his office, one of the glass-enclosed cubicles.  B hangs up his hat and raincoat, stows away the gloves and muffler.  Out of his coat pocket he takes a plastic anti- histamine sprayer and a box of cough drops, and still carrying the Kleenex, threads his way to his desk.  Most the desks are already occupied, and the others are fillin rapidly. Once seated at his desk, Bud arranges his medicaments nea in front of him. He takes a Kleenex out of the box, blows his nose, then leaning back in his swivel chair sprays fi one nostril, then the other. Suddenly the piercing bell g off -- the workday has begun. Being the ultra-conscientio type, Bud instantly sits upright in his chair, removes th cover from his computing machine, picks up a batch of perforated premium cards, starts entering figures on his computer. After a few seconds, he glances around to make sure that everybody in the vicinity is busy. Then he looks up a num in the company telephone directory, dials furtively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cupping hand over phone mouthpiece)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Dobisch? This is Baxter, on the nineteenth floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a glass-enclosed cubicle on the twenty-first floor. Through the glass we see another enormous layout of desks everybody working away. Dobisch is holding the phone in o hand, running an electric shaver over his face with the o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Buddy-boy. I was just about to call you. (shuts off electric shaver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about that mess on the living room wall. You see, my little friend, she kept insisting Picasso was a bum -- so she started to do that mural -- but I'm sure it will wash off -- just eyebrow pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Picasso I'm calling about. It's the key -- to my apartment -- you were supposed to leave it under the mat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, didn't I? I distinctly remember bending over and putting it there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I found a key there, all right -- only it's the wrong key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is? (takes Bud's key out of his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how about that? No wonder I couldn't get into the executive washroom this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I couldn't get into my apartment -- so at four a. m. I had to wake up the landlady and give her a whole song and dance about going out to mail a letter and the door slamming shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a shame. I'll send the key right down. And about your promotion -- (leafs through report on desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm sending that efficiency report right up to Mr. Sheldrake, in Personnel. I wouldn't be surprised if you heard from him before the day is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Dobisch. He hangs up, feels his forehead. It is warm. Clipped to h handkerchief pocket are a black fountain pen and, next to it, a thermometer in a black case. Bud unclips the thermometer case, unscrews the cap, shakes the thermomete out, puts it under his tongue. He resumes work. A messenger comes up to his desk with an interoffice enve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Mr. Dobisch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thermometer in mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. He turns away from the messenger, unties the string of th envelope, takes his key out, puts it in a coat pocket. Fr a trouser pocket, he extracts Dobisch's key to the execut washroom, slips it discreetly into the envelope, reties i hands it to the messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thermometer in mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Mr. Dobisch. Puzzled by the whole procedure, the messenger leaves. Bud now removes the thermometer from his mouth, reads it. It' worse than he thought. He puts the thermometer back in th case, clips it to his pocket, takes his desk calendar out a drawer, turns a leaf. Under the date WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBE there is an entry in his handwriting -- MR. VANDERHOF. Bu consults the telephone directory again, picks up the phon dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is another glass-enclosed cubicle on another floor. VANDERHOF, a Junior Chamber of Commerce type, is dictatin to an elderly secretary who sits across the desk from him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Mr. MacIntosh -- (phone rings and he picks it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanderhof, Public Relations. Oh, yes, Baxter. Just a minute. (to secretary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Miss Finch -- type up what we got so far. (he waits till she is out of the office; then, into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what is it, Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Vanderhof -- I've got you down here for tonight -- but I'm going to be using the place myself -- so I'll have to cancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cancel? But it's her birthday -- I already ordered the cake --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to disappoint you -- I mean, many happy returns -- but not tonight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not like you, Baxter. Just the other day, at the staff meeting, I was telling Mr. Sheldrake what a reliable man you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Vanderhof. But I'm sick -- I have this terrible cold -- and a fever -- and I got to go to bed right after work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy-boy, that's the worst thing you can do. If you got a cold, you should go to a Turkish bath -- spend the night there -- sweat it out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I'd get pneumonia -- and if I got pneumonia, I'd be in bed for a month -- and if I were in bed for a month --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you made your point. We'll just have to do it next Wednesday -- that's the only night of the week I can get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday -- Wednesday -- (leafing through calendar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got somebody penciled in -- let me see what I can do -- I'll get back to you. He hangs up, riffles through the directory, finds the number, and with a furtive look around, dials again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Eichelberger? Is this Mortgage and Loan? I'd like to speak to Mr. Eichelberger. Yes, it is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also glass-enclosed, but slightly larger than the others. EICHELBERGER, a solid citizen of about fifty, is displayi some mortgage graphs to three associates. A fourth one ha answered the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out phone to Eichelberger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, Mel. Eichelberger puts the charts down, takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eichelberger here -- oh, yes, Baxter -- (a glance at his associates; then continues, as though it were a business call)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your problem? -- Wednesday is out? -- oh -- that throws a little monkey wrench into my agenda -- Thursday? No, I'm all tied up on Thursday -- let's schedule that meeting for Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday? (checks calendar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see what I can do. I'll get back to you. He hangs up, consults the directory, starts to dial a num

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's another of those glass-enclosed cubicles, on the nineteenth floor. Kirkeby is talking into a dictaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Premium-wise and billing-wise, we are eighteen percent ahead of last year, October-wise. The phone has been ringing. Kirkeby switches off the mach picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yeah, Baxter. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of Friday -- could you possibly switch to Thursday? You'd be doing me a great favor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- it's all right with me, Bud. Let me check. I'll get back to you. He presses down the button on the cradle, dials Operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a double switchboard in the center, with nine gi on each side, all busy as beavers. In the foreground we recognize Sylvia, Kirkeby's date of last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consolidated Life -- I'll connect you -- Consolidated Life -- The girl next to her turns and holds out a line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia -- it's for you. Sylvia plugs the call into her own switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Oh, hello -- sure I got home all right -- you owe me forty-five cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Look, Sylvia -- instead of Friday - could we make it Thursday night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday? That's The Untouchables -- with Bob Stack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob WHO? -- all right, so we'll watch it at the apartment. Big deal. (he hangs up, dials)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter? It's okay for Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, at his desk, is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Kirkeby. (hangs up, consults directory, dials)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Eichelberger? It's okay for Friday. (hangs up, consults directory, dials)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Vanderhof? It's okay for Wednesday. During this, the phone has rung at the next desk, and the occupant, MR. MOFFETT, has picked it up. As Bud hangs up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- I'll tell him. (hangs up, turns to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Baxter -- that was Personnel. Mr. Sheldrake's secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheldrake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been trying to reach you for the last twenty minutes. They want you up stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! He jumps up, stuffs the nose-spray into one pocket, a handful of Kleenex into the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gives, Baxter? You getting promoted or getting fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cockily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care to make a small wager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been here twice as long as you have --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we say -- a dollar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bet. Bud snake-hips between the desks like a broken-field runn At the elevator, Bud presses the UP button, paces nervous One of the elevator doors opens, and as Bud starts inside the doors of the adjoining elevator open, and Fran Kubeli sticks her head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going up? Hearing her voice, Bud throws a quick "Excuse me" to the other operator, exits quickly and steps into Fran's eleva

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven, please. And drive carefully. You're carrying precious cargo -- I mean, manpower-wise. Fran shuts the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran presses a button, and the elevator starts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may not realize it, Miss Kubelik, but I'm in the top ten -- efficiency-wise and this may be the day -- promotion-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're beginning to sound like Mr. Kirkeby already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Now that they're kicking me upstairs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't happen to a nicer guy. (Bud beams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're the only one around here who ever takes his hat off in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The characters you meet. Something happens to men in elevators. Must be the change of altitude -- the blood rushes to their head, or something -- boy, I could tell you stories --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to hear them. Maybe we could have lunch in the cafeteria sometime -- or some evening, after work -- The elevator has stopped, and Fran opens the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is pretty plush up here -- soft carpeting and tall mahogany doors leading to the executive offices. The elev door is open, and Bud steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope everything goes all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. (turning back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you know they'd call me on a day like this -- with my cold and everything -- (fumbling with his tie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. (stepping out of elevator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. She takes the carnation out of her lapel, starts to put i in Bud's buttonhole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. That's the first thing I ever noticed about you -- when you were still on the local elevator -- you always wore a flower -- The elevator buzzer is now sounding insistently.  Fran st back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. And wipe your nose. She shuts the doors. Bud looks after her, then takes a Kleenex out of his pocket, and wiping his nose, crosses t glass door marked J. D. SHELDRAKE, DIRECTOR OF PERSONNEL. stashes the used Kleenex away in another pocket, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a sedate office with a secretary and a couple of typists. The secretary's name is MISS OLSEN. She is in he thirties, flaxen- haired, handsome, wears harlequin glass and has an incisive manner. Bud comes up to her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C. C. Baxter -- Ordinary Premium Accounting -- Mr. Sheldrake called me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called you -- that is, I tried to call you -- for twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on in. She indicates the door leading to the inner office. Bud squares his shoulders and starts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake is a $14,000 a year man, and rates a four- window office. It is not quite an executive suite, but it is several peg above the glass cubicles of the middle echelon. There is lots of leather, and a large desk behind which sits MR. SHELDRAKE. He is a substantial looking, authoritative man his middle forties, a pillar of his suburban community, a blood donor and a family man. The latter is attested to b framed photograph showing two boys, aged 8 and 10, in military school uniforms. As Baxter comes through the door, Sheldrake is leafing through Dobisch's efficiency report. He looks up at Bud through a pair of heavy-rimmed reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sort of wondering what you looked like. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Sheldrake. He seats himself on the very edge of the leather armchair facing Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been hearing some very nice things about you -- here's a report from Mr. Dobisch -- loyal, cooperative, resourceful --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dobisch said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mr. Kirkeby tells me that several nights a week you work late at the office -- without overtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (modestly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know how it is -- things pile up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Vanderhof, in Public Relations, and Mr. Eichelberger, in Mortgage and Loan -- they'd both like to have you transferred to their departments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very flattering. Sheldrake puts the report down, takes off his glasses, le across the desk toward Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Baxter -- just what is it that makes you so popular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think. Bud does so. For a moment, he is a picture of intense concentration. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind repeating the question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Baxter, I'm not stupid. I know everything that goes on in this building -- in every department -- on every floor -- every day of the year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a very small voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises, starts pacing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 1957, we had an employee here, name of Fowler. He was very popular, too. Turned out he was running a bookie joint right in the Actuarial Department tying up the switchboard, figuring the odds on our I.B.M. machines -- so the day before the Kentucky Derby, I called in the Vice Squad and we raided the thirteenth floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vice Squad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- what's that got to do with me? I'm not running any bookie joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of joint are you running?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a certain key floating around the office -- from Kirkeby to Vanderhof to Eichelberger to Dobisch -- it's the key to a certain apartment -- and you know who that apartment belongs to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loyal, cooperative, resourceful C. C. Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to deny it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I'm not going to deny it. But if you'd just let me explain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deep breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, about six months ago -- I was going to night school, taking this course in Advanced Accounting -- and one of the guys in our department -- he lives in Jersey -- he was going to a banquet at the Biltmore -- his wife was meeting him in town, and he needed someplace to change into a tuxedo -- so I gave him the key    and word must have gotten around -- because the next thing I knew, all sorts of guys were suddenly going to banquets -- and when you give the key to one guy, you can't say no to another and the whole thing got out of hand -- pardon me. He whips out the nasal-spray, administers a couple of qui squirts up each nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter, an insurance company is founded on public trust. Any employee who conducts himself in a manner unbecoming -- (shifting into a new gear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many charter members are there in this little club of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just those four -- out of a total of 31,259 -- so actually, we can be very proud of our personnel -- percentage-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point. Four rotten apples in a barrel -- no matter how large the barrel -- you realize that if this ever leaked out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it won't. Believe me. And it's not going to happen again. From now on, nobody is going to use my apartment -- In his vehemence he squeezes the spray bottle, which squi all over the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West 67th Street. You have no idea what I've been going through -- with the neighbors and the landlady and the liquor and the key --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you work it with the key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, usually I slip it to them in the office and they leave it under the mat -- but never again -- I can promise you that -- The phone buzzer sounds, and Sheldrake picks up the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Olsen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Olsen is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Sheldrake returning your call -- on two -- She presses a button down, starts to hang the phone up, glances around to see if the typists are watching, then raises the receiver to her ear and eavesdrops on the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheldrake is talking into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear -- I called you earlier -- where were you? Oh, you took Tommy to the dentist -- During this, Bud has risen from his chair, started inchin toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to intrude -- and I thought -- since it's all straightened out anyway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not through with you yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason I called is -- I won't be home for dinner tonight. The branch manager from Kansas City is in town -- I'm taking him to the theatre Music Man, what else? No, don't wait up for me -- 'bye, darling. (hangs up, turns to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something,  Baxter  -- have you seen Music Man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. But I hear it's one swell show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to go tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean -- you and me? I thought you were taking the branch manager from Kansas City --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made other plans. You can have both tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's very kind of you -- only I'm not feeling well -- you see, I have this cold -- and I thought I'd go straight home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter, you're not reading me. I told you I have plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I -- I'm going to take four aspirins and get into bed -- so you better give the tickets to somebody else --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not just giving those tickets, Baxter -- I want to swap them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swap them? For what? Sheldrake picks up the Dobisch reports, puts on his glass turns a page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It also says here -- that you are alert, astute, and quite imaginative --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? (the dawn is breaking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! He reaches into his coat pocket, fishes out a handful of Kleenex, and then finally the key to his apartment. He ho it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good thinking, Baxter. Next month there's going to be a shift in personnel around here -- and as far as I'm concerned, you're executive material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now put down the key -- (pushing a pad toward him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and put down the address. Bud lays the key on the desk, unclips what he thinks is h fountain pen, uncaps it, starts writing on the pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the second floor - my name is not on the door -- it just says

dialogues.speaker: 2A --
dialogues.text: Suddenly he realizes that he has been trying to write the address with the thermometer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- terribly sorry. It's that cold --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. He has replaced the thermometer with the fountain pen, an is scribbling the address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be careful with the record player, won't you? And about the liquor -- I ordered some this morning -- but I'm not sure when they'll deliver it -- He has finished writing the address, shoves the pad over Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now remember, Baxter -- this is going to be our little secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how people talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't have to worry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I have anything to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no sir. Certainly not. Anyway, it's none of my business -- four apples, five apples -- what's the difference -- percentage-wise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out the tickets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, Baxter. Have a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, sir. Clutching the tickets, he backs out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is about 6:30, and the building has pretty well emptie out by now. Bud, in raincoat and hat, is leaning against of the marble pillars beyond the elevators. His raincoat unbuttoned, and Fran's carnation is still in his lapel. H is looking off expectantly toward a door marked EMPLOYEES LOUNGE - WOMEN. Some of the female employees are emerging, dressed for th street. Among them are Sylvia and her colleague from the switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I figure, a man in his position, he's going to take me to 21 and El Morocco -- instead, he takes me to Hamburg Heaven and some schnook's apartment -- They pass Bud without paying any attention to him. Bud ha heard the crack, and looks after Sylvia, a little hurt. T he glances back toward the door of the lounge, as it open and Fran Kubelik comes out. She is wearing a wool coat ov a street dress, no hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. She is about three paces beyond him when he suddenly real who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Miss Kubelik. (he rushes after her, taking off his hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost didn't recognize you -- this is the first time I've ever seen you in civilian clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you make out on the twenty- seventh floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Look -- have you seen The Music Man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe we could have a bite to eat first -- and then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I can't tonight. I'm meeting somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean -- like a girl-friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Like a man. She proceeds across the lobby toward the street entrance, Bud following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't trying to be personal -- it's just that the fellows in the office were -- whether you wondering about you ever --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell 'em -- now and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This date -- is it just a date -- or is it something serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It used to be serious -- at least I was -- but he wasn't -- so the whole thing is more or less kaputt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in that case, couldn't you -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. I promised to have a drink with him -- he's been calling me all week --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I understand. He follows her out through the revolving doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran and Bud come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his hat on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was just an idea -- I hate to see a ticket go to waste --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time does the show go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I could meet you at the theatre -- if that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right? That's wonderful! It's the Majestic -- 44th Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet you in the lobby. Okay? Bud nods happily, falls in beside her as she starts down street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I felt so lousy this morning -- a hundred and one fever -- then my promotion came up -- now you and I -- eleventh row center -- and you said I should have stayed in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high as a kite)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What cold? And after the show, we could go out on the town -- (does a little cha cha step)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been taking from Arthur Murray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got a great little band at El Chico, in the Village -- it's practically around the corner from where you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good. (a sudden thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know where I live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I even know who you live with -- your sister and brother-in- law -- I know when you were born -- and where -- I know all sorts of things about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of months ago I looked up your card in the group insurance file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know your height, your weight and your Social Security number -- you had mumps, you had measles, and you had your appendix out. They have now reached the corner, and Fran stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't tell the fellows in the office about the appendix. They may get the wrong idea how you found out. (turning the corner)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-thirty! He watches her walk away, an idiot grin on his face. Desp what he told Fran, his nose is stuffed up, so he takes ou the anti-histamine and sprays his nostrils. Then, carried away, he squirts some of the stuff on the carnation in hi buttonhole, moves off in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran comes hurrying along the street. She is late. Her objective is a small Chinese restaurant, with a neon sign reading THE RICKSHAW - COCKTAILS - CANTONESE FOOD. She starts down a flight of steps leading to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is a long, narrow, dimly-lit room with booths alo one side. Beyond a bamboo curtain is the main dining room which does not concern us. The place is decorated in Earl Beachcomber style rattan, fish-nets, conch-shells, etc. The help is Chinese. At this early hour, there are only h a dozen customers in the place -- all at the bar except f one man, sitting in the last booth with his back toward camera. At a piano, a Chinese member of Local 808 is improvising mood music. Fran comes through the door, and without looking around, heads straight for the last booth. The bartender nods to her -- they know her there. As she passes the piano playe he gives her a big smile, segues into JEALOUS LOVER. Fran comes up to the man sitting in the last booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wistful smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Sheldrake. Sheldrake, for that's who it is, looks around nervously t make sure no one has heard her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Fran -- not so loud. (he gets up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still afraid somebody may see us together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for her coat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jeff. I can't stay very long. (sits opposite him, with her coat on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a frozen daiquiri?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the way. (sits down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you went ahead and cut your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I liked it better long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. You want a lock to carry in your wallet? A waiter comes up with a tray: two daiquiris, fried shrim eggrolls, and a bowl of sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing all his teeth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, lady. Nice see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. The waiter has set everything on the table, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been -- a month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six weeks. But who's counting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed you, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like old times. Same booth, same song --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dipping shrimp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- same sauce -- sweet and sour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what it's like -- standing next to you in that elevator, day after day -- Good morning, Miss Kubelik -- Good night, Mr. Sheldrake -- I'm still crazy about you, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (avoiding his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not start on that again, Jeff -- please. I'm just beginning to get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jeff -- we had two wonderful months this summer -- and that was it. Happens all the time -- the wife and kids go away to the country, and the boss has a fling with the secretary or the manicurist -- or the elevator girl. Comes September, the picnic is over -- goodbye. The kids go back to school, the boss goes back to the wife, and the girl -- (she is barely able to control herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't make these shrimp like they used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said goodbye, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a while there, you try kidding yourself that you're going with an unmarried man. Then one day he keeps looking at his watch, and asks you if there's any lipstick showing, then rushes off to catch the seven-fourteen to White Plains. So you fix yourself a cup of instant coffee -- and you sit there by yourself -- and you think -- and it all begins to look so ugly -- There are tears in her eyes. She breaks off, downs what's left of the daiquiri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think I felt -- riding home on that seven-fourteen train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you keep calling me, Jeff? What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you back, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (withdrawing her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Sheldrake -- I'm full up. You'll have to take the next elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not giving me a chance, Fran. I asked you to meet me because -- I have something to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead -- tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a glance around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here, Fran. Can't we go some place else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I have a date at eight-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very -- but I'm going to be there anyway. She takes out an inexpensive square compact with a fleur lis pattern on it, opens it, starts to fix her face. The waiter comes up with a couple of menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready order dinner now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring us two more drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is 8:25, and there is the usual hectic to-do -- taxis pulling up, people milling around the sidewalk and crowdi into the lobby. In the middle of this melee, buffeted by throng, stands Bud, in raincoat and hat, looking anxiousl for Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran and Sheldrake, in the booth, are working on the seco round of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran -- remember that last weekend we had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I. That leaky little boat you rented -- and me in a black negligee and a life preserver --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what we talked about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We talked about a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- about my getting a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't talk about it -- you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't really believe me, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got it an a long playing record now - Music to String Her Along By. My wife doesn't understand me -- We haven't gotten along for years -- You're the best thing that ever happened to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going right on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just trust me, baby -- we'll work it out somehow --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not being funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll just listen to me for a minute --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw my lawyer this morning -- I wanted his advice  -- about the best way to handle it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handle what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him for a long moment - then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get something straight, Jeff -- I never asked you to leave your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. You had nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes misting up again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure that's what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure. If you'll just tell me that you still love me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran -- He takes her hand, kisses it. The bar has been filling up and now two couples are seating themselves in a nearby bo One of the women is Miss Olsen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling her hand away gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff -- darling -- She indicates the other customers. Sheldrake glances over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is crowding up. Let's get out of here. They rise. Sheldrake leaves some money on the table, lead Fran toward the entrance. As they pass Miss Olsen's booth she turns around slowly, and putting on her glasses, look after them. Sheldrake slips a bill to the piano player, who gives the big smile, slides into JEALOUS LOVER again. Retrieving hi hat and coat from the checkroom girl, Sheldrake steers Fr through the door. Miss Olsen watches them with a cold smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran and Sheldrake come up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a passing cab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taxi! It passes without stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have that date -- remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you -- remember? Another taxi approaches. Sheldrake gives a shrill whistle and it pulls up. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going, Jeff? Not back to that leaky boat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise. He helps her into the cab, takes out of his coat pocket t page from the pad on which Bud wrote the address of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cab driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 West Sixty-Seventh. He gets in beside Fran, shuts the door. As the cab pulls away, through the rear window the two can be seen kissing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 9 o'clock, the lobby is deserted, and standing on th sidewalk all by himself, is Bud. He takes a Kleenex out o his pocket, blows his nose, stuffs the used Kleenex in another pocket. He looks up and down the street, consults his watch, decides to wait just a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER'S DESK CALENDAR
dialogues.text: The leaves are flipping over. Mr. Sheldrake seems to be using The Apartment regularly -- for the name Sheldrake, Bud's handwriting, appears on the pages dated Monday, November 9, Thursday, November 12, Thursday, November 19, Monday, November 23, and Monday, November 30. Mr. Sheldra also seems to be Baxter's only customer by now, since the other leaves of the calendar are blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a gloomy December morning, and hundreds of desk-bou employees are bent over their paper-work. Bud Baxter, in raincoat and hat, is clearing out his desk He has piled everything on his blotter pad -- reference books, papers, a fountain pen set, pencils, paper clips a the calendar. Watching him from the next desk is a dumbfounded Moffett. Bud picks up the blotter pad with hi stuff on it, and as he moves past Moffett's desk, Moffett takes out a dollar bill, drops it grudgingly on the loade pad.
