Bud flashes him a little grin, continues between the desks toward the row of glass-enclosed offices housing th supervisory personnel. He comes up to an unoccupied cubicle. A sign painter is brushing in some new lettering on the glass door -- it re C. C. BAXTER, Second Administrative Assistant. Bud studie the sign with a good deal of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to painter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind --? (the painter turns around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C. C. Baxter -- that's me. With an "Oh, " the painter opens the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud enters his new office, deposits his stuff on the bare desk, looks around possessively. The small cubicle boasts one window, carpeting on the floor, a filing cabinet, a couple of synthetic-leather chairs, and a clothes-tree -- Bud, it is the Taj Mahal. He crosses to the clothes-tree, removes his hat and coat, hangs them up. From OFF comes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Buddy-boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, and all that jazz. Bud turns. Kirkeby, Dobisch, Eichelberger and Vanderhof h come into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you made it, kid -- just like we promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite an office -- name on the door -- rug on the floor -- the whole schmear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teamwork -- that's what counts in an organization like this. All for one and one for all -- know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a vague idea. Kirkeby signals to Vanderhof, who shuts the door. The fou charter members of the club start closing in on Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter, we're a little disappointed in you -- gratitude-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you locking us out, all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been sort of rough these last few weeks -- what with my cold and like that -- He has picked up the desk calendar, shoves it discreetly into one of the drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went to bat for you -- and now you won't play ball with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, after all, it's my apartment -- it's private property -- it's not a public playground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, so you got yourself a girl -- that's okay with us -- but not every night of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How selfish can you get? (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last week I had to borrow my nephew's car and take Sylvia to a drive-in in Jersey. I'm too old for that sort of thing -- I mean, in a Volkswagen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sympathize with your problem -- and believe me, I'm very sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be a lot sorrier before we're through with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You threatening me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Baxter, we made you and we can break you. He deliberately flips a cigar ash on Bud's desk. At the s time, the door opens, and Sheldrake comes striding in bri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Sheldrake. The others swivel around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, gentlemen. (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything satisfactory? You like your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir. Very much. And I want to thank you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me -- thank your friends here -- they're the ones who recommended you. The four friends manage to work up some sickly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just dropped in to wish him the best. (quickly brushes cigar ash off desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they move toward the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Baxter. We know you won't let us down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, fellas. Drop in any time. The door is always open -- to my office. They leave. Sheldrake and Bud are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the way you handled that. Well, how does it feel to be an executive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. And I want you to know I'll work very hard to justify your confidence in me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you will. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Baxter, about the apartment - now that you got a raise, don't you think we can afford a second key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my secretary -- Miss Olsen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Very attractive. Is she -- the lucky one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't understand. She's a busybody -- always poking her nose into things -- and with that key passing back and forth -- why take chances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You can't be too careful. He glances toward the glass partitions to make sure that nobody is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something here -- I think it belongs to you. Out of his pocket he has slipped the compact with the fle de-lis pattern we saw Fran use at the Rickshaw. He holds out to Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- the young lady -- whoever she may be -- it was on the couch when I got home last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mirror is broken. (opens compact, revealing crack in mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was broken when I found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it was. (takes the compact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She threw it at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how it is -- sooner or later they all give you a bad time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (man-of-the-world)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see a girl a couple of times a week -- just for laughs -- and right away she thinks you're going to divorce your wife. I ask you -- is that fair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. That's very unfair -- especially to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (shifting gears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Baxter, I envy you. Bachelor -- all the dames you want -- no headaches, no complications --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. That's the life, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me down for Thursday again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger. And I'll get that other key. Sheldrake exits. Bud takes the calendar out of the desk drawer, makes an entry.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER'S DESK CALENDAR
dialogues.text: Again the leaves are flipping over, and again we see Sheldrake's name in Bud's handwriting -- booked for the following dates: Monday, December 14, Thursday, December Monday, December 21, Thursday, December 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perched on top of the switchboard is a small decorated Christmas tree, and the operators are dispensing holiday greetings to all callers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consolidated Life -- Merry Christmas -- I'll connect you -- Consolidated Life -- Merry Christmas -- I'm ringing -- In the foreground, Sylvia is engaged in a private conversation of her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mouthpiece)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? -- YEAH? -- Where? -- You bet -- She tears off her headset, and turns to the other girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody watch my line -- there's a swinging party up on the nineteenth floor -- She scoots out the door. The other girls immediately aban their posts, and dash after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a swinging party, all right. Nobody is working. Seve desks have been cleared and pushed together, and on top o this improvised stage four female employees and Mr. Dobis with his pants-legs rolled up, are doing a Rockette kick routine to the tune of JINGLE BELLS. Employees are ringed around the performers, some drinking out of paper cups, others singing and clapping in rhythm. One of the cubicles has been transformed into a bar, and is jammed with people. Mr. Kirkeby and Mr. Vanderhof are pouring -- each has a couple of bottles of liquor in his hands, and is emptying them into the open top of a water- cooler. But the stuff is flowing out as fast as it flows in -- everybody is in line with a paper cup waiting for a refil Bud comes shouldering his way out of the crowded cubicle, holding aloft two paper cups filled with booze. Since his promotion he has bought himself a new suit, dark flannel, and with it he wears a white shirt with a pinned round collar, and a foulard tie. He also has quite a glow on. Detouring past necking couples, he heads in the direction the elevators. The doors of Fran's elevator are just opening, and the switchboard operators, led by Sylvia, come streaming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a colleague)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so I said to him: Never again! -- either get yourself a bigger car or a smaller girl -- As they head for the party, they pass Bud, who is approac the elevator with the two drinks. Fran is just closing th elevator doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik. The doors slide open again, and Fran looks out. Instead o the customary carnation in the lapel of her uniform, she wears a sprig of holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out one of the drinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (takes drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were avoiding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gave you that idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the last six weeks you've only been in my elevator once -- and then you didn't take your hat off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as a matter of fact, I was rather hurt when you stood me up that night --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you. It was unforgivable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't help yourself. I mean, when you're having a drink with one man, you can't just suddenly walk out on him because you have another date with another man. You did the only decent thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too sure. Just because I wear a uniform -- that doesn't make me a Girl Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik, one doesn't get to be a second administrative assistant around here unless he's a pretty good judge of character -- and as far as I'm concerned, you're tops. I mean, decency-wise -- and otherwise-wise. (toasting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. They down their drinks. Bud takes the empty cup from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating elevator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't drink when I'm driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so right. He reaches into the elevator, takes a cardboard sign off hook, hangs it on the elevator door. It reads USE OTHER ELEVATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the power vested in me, I herewith declare this elevator out of order. (leading her toward the party)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we join the natives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? (as they pass a kissing couple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem friendly enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you believe it. Later on there will be human sacrifices -- white collar workers tossed into the computing machines, and punched full of those little square holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of those drinks did you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up four fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so. They have now reached the entrance to the bar, which is overflowing with thirsty natives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wait here. I think I hear the sound of running water. He leaves her outside the cubicle, and elbows his way through the crowd toward the booze-filled water cooler. O of another cubicle comes Miss Olsen, cup in hand. She too has had quite a few. Seeing Fran, she walks up to her, wi an acid smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. How's the branch manager from Kansas City?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Miss Olsen -- Mr. Sheldrake's secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't have to play innocent with me. He used to tell his wife that I was the branch manager from Seattle -- four years ago when we were having a little ring-a-ding- ding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And before me there was Miss Rossi in Auditing -- and after me there was Miss Koch in Disability -- and just before you there was Miss What's-Her-Name, on the twenty- fifth floor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wanting to get away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding her by the arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? You haven't done anything -- it's him -- what a salesman -- always the last booth in the Chinese restaurant -- and the same pitch about divorcing his wife -- and in the end you wind up with egg foo yong on your face. Bud comes burrowing out of the crowded cubicle, balancing the two filled paper cups, spots Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik. Fran turns away from Miss Olsen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always happy to do something for our girls in uniform. She moves off as Bud joins Fran, who is looking a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (takes the drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are just too many people here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we step into any office? There's something I want your advice about, anyway. (leads her toward his cubicle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my own office now, naturally. And you may be interested to know I'm the second youngest executive in the company -- the only one younger is a grandson of the chairman of the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud ushers Fran in, and is confronted by a strange couple necking in the corner. He gestures them out, crosses to h desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik, I would like your honest opinion. I've had this in my desk for a week -- cost me fifteen dollars -- but I just couldn't get up enough nerve to wear it -- From under the desk he has produced a hatbox, and out of hatbox a black bowler, which he now puts on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what they call the junior executive model. What do you think? Fran looks at him blankly, absorbed in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I made a boo-boo, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (paying attention again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You mean you wouldn't be ashamed to be seen with somebody in a hat like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if I wore it a little more to the side -- (adjusting hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is that better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as long as you wouldn't be ashamed to be seen with me -- how about the three of us going out this evening -- you and me and the bowler -- stroll down Fifth Avenue -- sort of break it in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a bad day for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. Christmas -- family and all that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better get back to my elevator. I don't want to be fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't have to worry about that. I have quite a bit of influence in Personnel. You know Mr. Sheldrake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guardedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and I are like this. (crosses his fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sent me a Christmas card. See? He has picked up a Christmas card from his desk, shows it Fran. It is a photograph of the Sheldrake clan grouped around an elaborate Christmas tree -- Mr. and Mrs. Sheldrake, the two boys in military school uniforms, and big French poodle. Underneath it says: SEASON'S GREETINGS from the SHELDRAKES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, Jeff, Tommy, Jeff Jr., and Figaro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the card ruefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes a cute picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe I could put in a word for you with Mr. Sheldrake -- get you a little promotion -- how would you like to be an elevator starter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there are too many other girls around here with seniority over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. Why don't we discuss it sometime over the holidays -- I could call you and pick you up and we'll have the big unveiling -- (touching the brim of his bowler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you sure this is the right way to wear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think it's tilted a little too much -- Fran takes her compact out of her uniform pocket, opens i hands it to Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (examining himself in the mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, this is a conservative firm -- I don't want people to think I'm an entertainer -- His voice trails off. There is something familiar about t cracked mirror of the compact -- and the fleur-de-lis pattern on the case confirms his suspicion. Fran notices peculiar expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mirror -- it's broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I like it this way -- makes me look the way I feel. The phone has started to ring. Bud doesn't hear it. He closes the compact, hands it to Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (picks up phone from desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? (throws a quick look at Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. (covers mouthpiece; to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind -- this is sort of personal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Have a nice Christmas. She exits, closing the door. Bud takes his hand off the mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (every word hurts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Sheldrake -- no, I didn't forget -- the tree is up and the Tom and Jerry mix is in the refrigerator -- yes, sir -- same to you. He hangs up, stands there for a moment, the bowler still his head, the noise from the party washing over him. He slowly crosses to the clothes-tree. picks up his coat -- new, black chesterfield. With the coat over his arm, he starts out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party has picked up tempo. On top of the desks, Sylvi is doing a mock strip tease -- without taking any clothes off. There is hollering, drinking and clapping all around Bud moves past the floor show, paying no attention. Kirke spots him, detaches himself from the cheering section aro Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going, Buddy-boy? The party's just starting. (catching up with him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, kid -- give me a break, will you -- how about tomorrow afternoon? I can't take her to that drive-in again -- the car doesn't even have a heater four o'clock -- okay? Bud ignores him, continues walking through the ranks of empty desks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is six o'clock, and the joint is crowded with customer having one for the road before joining their families for Christmas Eve. There are men with gaily wrapped packages, small trussed-up Christmas trees, a plucked turkey in a plastic bag. Written across the mirror behind the bar, in glittering white letters, is HAPPY HOLIDAYS. Everybody is high spirits, laughing it up and toasting each other. Everybody except Bud Baxter. He is standing at the bar in his chesterfield and bowler, slightly isolated, brooding over an almost empty martini glass. The bartender comes u sets down a fresh martini with an olive on a toothpick, takes his payment from a pile of bills and coins lying in front of Bud. Bud fishes out the olive, adds it to half a dozen other impaled olives neatly arranged in fan shape o the counter. He is obviously trying to complete the circl A short, rotund man dressed as Santa Claus hurries in fro the street, and comes up to the bar beside Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bartender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charlie -- give me a shot of bourbon -- and step on it -- my sleigh is double parked. He laughs uproariously at his own joke, nudges Bud with h elbow. Bud stares at him coldly, turns back to his martin The laughter dies in Santa Claus' throat. He gets his sho of bourbon, moves down the bar to find more convivial com Standing near the end of the curved bar is a girl in her middle twenties wearing a ratty fur coat. Her name is MAR MacDOUGALL, she is drinking a Rum Collins through a straw and she too is alone. From a distance, she is studying Bu with interest. On the bar in front of her is a container straws in paper wrappers. She takes one of them out, tear off the end of the paper, blows through the straw -- send the wrapper floating toward Bud. The paper wrapper passes right in front of Bud's nose. He doesn't notice it. Margie, undaunted, lets go with another missile. This time the wrapper lands on the brim of Bud's bowler. reaction. Another wrapper comes floating in, hits Bud's cheek. He never takes his eye off his martini. Margie leaves her place, and carrying her handbag and her empty glass, comes up alongside Bud. Without a word, she reaches up and removes the wrapper from Bud's bowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You buy me a drink, I'll buy you some music. (sets the glass down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rum Collins. Not waiting for an answer, she heads for the juke box. Bu looks after her noncommittally, then turns to the bartend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rum Collins. (indicating martini glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And another one of these little mothers. At the juke box, Margie has dropped a coin in and made he selection. The music starts -- ADESTE FIDELIS. She rejoin Bud at the bar just as the bartender is putting down thei drinks in front of them. Bud removes the new olive, adds to the pattern on the counter in front of him. They both drink, staring straight ahead. For quite a while, there i complete silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of nowhere)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like Castro? (a blank look from Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- how do you feel about Castro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is Castro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that big-shot down in Cuba with the crazy beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because as far as I'm concerned, he's a no good fink. Two weeks ago I wrote him a letter -- never even answered me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I wanted him to do was let Mickey out for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Mickey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband. He's in Havana -- in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Mixed up in that revolution?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey? He wouldn't do nothing like that. He's a jockey. They caught him doping a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't win 'em all. They sit there silently for a moment, contemplating the injustices of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Twas the night before Christmas And all through the house Not a creature was stirring -- Nothing -- No action -- Dullsville! (drinks; to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night like this, it sort of spooks you to walk into an empty apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I had no family -- I didn't say I had an empty apartment. They both drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is dark, except for a shaft of light from the kitchen, and the glow of the colored bulbs on a small Christmas tree in front of the phony fireplace. Hunched up in one corner of the couch is Fran, still in h coat and gloves, crying softly. Pacing up and down is Sheldrake. His coat and hat are on a chair, as are severa Christmas packages. On the coffee table are an unopened bottle of Scotch, a couple of untouched glasses, and a bo of melting ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops and faces Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Fran -- don't be like that. You just going to sit there and keep bawling? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't talk to me, you won't tell me what's wrong -- (a new approach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know you think I'm stalling you. But when you've been married to a woman for twelve years, you don't just sit down at the breakfast table and say "Pass the sugar -- and I want a divorce." It's not that easy. (he resumes pacing; Fran continues crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, this is the wrong time. The kids are home from school -- my in- laws are visiting for the holidays -- I can't bring it up now. (stops in front of her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't like you, Fran -- you were always such a good sport -- such fun to be with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- that's me. The Happy Idiot -- a million laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's more like it. At least you're speaking to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing happened to me at the office party today -- I ran into your secretary -- Miss Olsen. You know -- ring-a-ding-ding? I laughed so much I like to died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what's been bothering you -- Miss Olsen? That's ancient history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never very good at history. Let me see -- there was Miss Olsen, and then there was Miss Rossi -- no, she came before -- it was Miss Koch who came after Miss Olsen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Fran --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just think -- right now there's some lucky girl in the building who's going to come after me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, Fran. I deserve that. But just ask yourself -- why does a man run around with a lot of girls? Because he's unhappy at home -- because he's lonely, that's why -- all that was before you, Fran -- I've stopped running. Fran has taken a handkerchief out of her bag and is dabbi her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I be so stupid? You'd think I would have learned by now -- when you're in love with a married man, you shouldn't wear mascara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Christmas Eve, Fran -- let's not fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. She hands him a flat, wrapped package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? He strips away the wrapping to reveal a long-playing reco The cover reads: RICKSHAW BOY - Jimmy Lee Kiang with Orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Our friend from the Chinese restaurant. Thanks, Fran. We better keep it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a present for you. I didn't quite know what to get you -- anyway it's a little awkward for me, shopping -- (he has taken out a money clip, detaches a bill)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so here's a hundred dollars -- go out and buy yourself something. He holds the money out, but she doesn't move. Sheldrake slips the bill into her open bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have some nice alligator bags at Bergdorf's -- Fran gets up slowly and starts peeling off her gloves. Sheldrake looks at her, then glances nervously at his wri watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran, it's a quarter to seven -- and I mustn't miss the train -- if we hadn't wasted all that time -- I have to get home and trim the tree -- Fran has started to remove her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (shrugs the coat back on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought as long as it was paid for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an angry step toward her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever talk like that, Fran! Don't make yourself out to be cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred dollars? I wouldn't call that cheap. And you must be paying somebody something for the use of the apartment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing her arms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll miss your train, Jeff. Sheldrake hurriedly puts on his hat and coat, gathers up packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You run along -- I want to fix my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heading for the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to kill the lights. See you Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Monday and Thursday -- and Monday again -- and Thursday again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (that stops him in the half-open door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't always be like this. (coming back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Fran. Holding the packages to one side, he tries to kiss her on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful -- lipstick. He kisses her on the cheek, hurries out of the apartment, closing the door. Fran stands there for a while, blinking back tears, then takes the long-playing record out of its envelope, crosses to the phonograph. She puts the record starts the machine -- the music is JEALOUS LOVER. As it plays, Fran wanders aimlessly around the darkened room, h body wracked by sobs. Finally she regains control of hers and picking up her handbag, starts through the bedroom toward the bathroom. In the bathroom, Fran switches on the light, puts her bag the sink, turns on the faucet. Scooping up some water, sh washes the smeared mascara away, then turns the faucet of picks up a towel As she is drying her face, she notices i the pull-away shaving mirror the magnified reflection of vial of pills on the medicine shelf. Fran reaches out for the vial, turns it slowly around in her hand. The label reads: SECONAL - ONE AT BEDTIME AS NEEDED FOR SLEEP. Fran studies the label for a second, then returns the via to the shelf. She opens her handbag, takes out a lipstick As she does so, she sees the hundred dollar bill Sheldrak left in the bag. Her eyes wander back to the vial on the medicine shelf. Then very deliberately she picks up Bud's mouthwash glass, removes the two toothbrushes from it, tu on the faucet, starts filling the glass with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joint is deserted now except for the Santa Claus, who leaning against the bar, quite loaded, and Bud and Margie MacDougall, who are dancing to a slow blues coming from t juke box. Bud is still in his overcoat and bowler, and Margie is wearing her fur coat. The bartender is sweeping the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Santa Claus)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink up, Pop. It's closing time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's early, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know what night this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Charlie. I know. I work for the outfit. He polishes off his drink, walks out unsteadily. The bartender approaches the dancers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, knock it off, will you? Go home. Bud and Margie ignore him, continue dancing -- or rather swaying limply cheek-to-cheek. The bartender crosses to t juke box, pulls the plug out. The music stops, but not Bu and Margie -- they continue dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O-U-T -- out! He goes to the front of the bar, starts to extinguish the lights. Margie picks up her handbag from the bar, and Bud downs the remains of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we go -- my place or yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might as well go to mine -- everybody else does. He leads her through the dark bar toward the entrance. Th bartender holds the door open for them as they go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud and Margie come walking down the street. As they reac the house, Bud starts up the steps, but Margie continues along the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Mickey -- when I think of him all by himself in that jail in Havana -- (opening her handbag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- want to see his picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from steps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly. Margie, realizing her mistake, hurries back to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so cute -- five-foot-two -- ninety-nine pounds...like a little chihuahua. They pass through the front door into the vestibule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud and Margie are mounting the stairs toward the apartme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a girl-friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She may be a girl -- but she's no friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still stuck on her, huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuck on her! Obviously, you don't know me very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permit me -- C.C. Baxter -- junior executive, Arthur Murray graduate, lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mrs. MacDougall -- Margie to you. Bud has taken the key out of his pocket, opened the door his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Mrs. MacDougall. He ushers her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is exactly the way we left it. There is no sign of Fra except for the gloves she dropped on the coffee table earlier. Bud switches on the light, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, this is Snugsville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping her out of her coat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacDougall, I think it is only fair to warn you that you are now alone with a notorious sexpot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a gleam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask anybody around here. As a matter of fact, when it's time for me to go -- and I may go just like that -- (snaps his fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I have promised my body to the Columbia Medical Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuddering deliciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee. Sort of gives you goose-bumps just to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they haven't got me yet, baby. Dig up some ice from the kitchen and let's not waste any time -- preliminary-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with you, lover. She takes the bowl of melted ice Bud has handed her, disappears into the kitchen. As Bud starts to remove his coat, he becomes aware of a scratching noise from the phonograph. He crosses to it, sees that the needle is stu in the last groove of a long-playing record. Bud lifts the record off, examines it curiously, then put it aside and substitutes the cha cha record. As the music starts, he dances over to the coat-rack beside the door, hangs up his chesterfield and bowler. He turns back into room, still dancing, suddenly spots Fran's gloves on the coffee table. He picks up the gloves, looks around for so convenient place to get rid of them. Moving over to the bedroom door, he opens it, tosses the gloves toward the b inside. He shuts the door, starts to turn away, freezes i delayed reaction to something he saw inside. He quickly opens the door again, looks. Sprawled across the bed, on top of the bedspread, is Fran The light from the bathroom falls across her. She is full dressed, still in her coat, and apparently asleep. Bud steps into the bedroom, closing the door behind him, walks over to Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Miss Kubelik -- get up. It's past checking-out time, and the hotel management would appreciate it if you would get the hell out of here. (Fran doesn't stir)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Miss Kubelik, I used to like you -- I used to like you a lot -- but it's all over between us -- so beat it -- O-U-T -- out! (no reaction; he puts a hand on her shoulder, shakes her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- wake up! She doesn't respond. But something falls out of her hand, rolls across the bed. Bud picks it up, looks at it -- it his sleeping-pill vial, now uncapped and empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hoarse whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. For a second he is paralyzed. Then he drops the vial, gra Fran, lifts her into a sitting position on the bed, shake her violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik! Miss Kubelik! Fran's head droops to one side, like a rag doll's. Bud le go of her, rushes out. In the living room, the phonograph is still cha cha-ing a Bud dashes to the phone, picks it up. Then it occurs to h that he doesn't know whom to call and he hangs up. Out of the kitchen comes Margie, with a bowlful of ice cubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I broke a nail trying to get the ice-tray out. You ought to buy yourself a new refrigerator. Bud, not listening, runs past her to the hall door and ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud arrives at the door of the Dreyfuss apartment, starts ringing the doorbell and pounding with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Dreyfuss! Hey, Doc! The door opens, and Dr. Dreyfuss stands there sleepily, pulling on his beaten bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (words tumbling over each other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a girl in my place -- she took some sleeping pills -- you better come quick -- I can't wake her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get my bag. He disappears from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Doc. Bud turns and runs back into his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margie has settled herself comfortably on the couch, and fixing the drinks. The cha cha music is still going. Bud comes flying in, heads for the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- over here, lover. Bud stops in his tracks, suddenly aware of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this running around? You're going to wear yourself out. Bud strides over to her purposefully, yanks her up to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so rough, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the glass out of her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrusting the fur coat at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Did I do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easing her toward door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an emergency -- see you some other time. Dr. Dreyfuss comes hurrying in, carrying his medical bag. stops, bewildered by the sound of music and the sight of wide-awake girl in the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this one -- (pointing to the bedroom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in there, Doc. Dr. Dreyfuss proceeds into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what's going on here, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (propelling her toward the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just clear out, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shoes. Bud reaches under the coffee table, where she left her shoes, retrieves them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some lover you are. Some sexpot! Bud shoves the shoes at her, takes a bill out of his wall hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- find yourself a phone booth and call your husband in Havana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I will. And when I tell him how you treated me, he'll push your face in. (he shoves her through the open door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fink! Bud slams the door shut, starts toward the bedroom. Halfw there, he becomes aware that the cha cha record is still He detours to the phonograph, switches it off, continues into the bedroom. In the bedroom, the overhead light is on, and Dr. Dreyfus is working on the unconscious Fran. He has removed her co and is shining a flashlight into her eyes, examining her pupils. Bud approaches the bed worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She going to be all right, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many pills were in that bottle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was half-full -- about a dozen or so. You going to have to take her to the hospital? Dr. Dreyfuss ignores him. Out of his medical bag, he take stomach tube with a rubber funnel at the end. Then he sta to lift Fran off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me, will you? Between them, they get Fran into an upright position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the bathroom. They half-carry, half-drag Fran's limp form toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that stuff out of her stomach -- if it isn't too late. You better put some coffee on -- and pray. Bud starts away as Dr. Dreyfuss takes Fran into the bathr Bud loses no time getting into the kitchen. He fills an aluminum kettle with water, strikes a match, lights the g burner, puts the kettle on. Then he takes a jar of instan coffee and a chipped coffee mug out of the cupboard, shak an excessive portion of coffee into the mug, sticks a spo in it. He watches the kettle for a moment, mops his brow with a handkerchief, then starts back toward the bedroom. Bud crosses the bedroom to the half-open door of the bathroom, looks in anxiously. From inside come the sounds a coughing spasm and running water. Bud turns away, undoe his tie and collar, paces the bedroom floor. Something on the night table attracts his attention -- resting against the base of the lamp is a sealed envelope. Bud picks it up -- on it, in Fran's handwriting, is one word, JEFF. He turns the letter over in his hand, trying to decide what do with it. Dr. Dreyfuss emerges from the bathroom, carrying a pale, still unconscious Fran. Bud quickly conceals the suicide note behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring my bag. He lugs Fran into the living room. Bud stashes the letter his back pocket, picks up the medical bag, follows them. In the living room, Dr. Dreyfuss lowers Fran into a chair Her chin falls to her chest. Dreyfuss takes the bag from Bud, fishes out a hypodermic syringe, draws 2 c.c.'s from bottle of picrotoxin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll up her right sleeve. Bud does so. Dr. Dreyfuss hands the hypodermic to Bud, searches for a spot for the injection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice veins. He swabs the spot with alcohol, takes the hypodermic back from Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I mean -- I wasn't here -- you see -- we had some words earlier -- nothing serious, really -- what you might call a lovers' quarrel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making off-scene injection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you went right out and picked yourself up another dame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Baxter, you're a real cutie-pie -- yes, you are. Bud just stands there, taking it. Fran stirs slightly, an from her parched lips comes a low moan. Dr. Dreyfuss grab her by the hair, lifts her head up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd come home half an hour later, you would have had quite a Christmas present. With his free hand, Dr. Dreyfuss slaps Fran viciously acr the face. Bud winces. Dreyfuss, still holding Fran by the hair, takes a box of ammonia ampules out of his bag. He crushes one of the ampules in his hand, passes it under h nose. Fran tries to turn her head away. Dreyfuss slaps he again, hard, crushes another ampule, repeats the process. Bud is watching tensely. From the kitchen comes the whist of the boiling kettle, but Bud pays no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the coffee. Bud hurries into the kitchen. He turns off the gas, pours the boiling water into the mug with the instant coffee, stirs it. From off, come the sounds of more slapping and some moaning. Bud carries the coffee out. In the living room, Dr. Dreyfuss is working another ammon ampule under Fran's nose. Her eyes start fluttering. Drey takes the coffee mug from Bud, forces it between Fran's lips, pours coffee into her mouth. Fran resists instinctively, half the coffee dribbling over her chin an dress, but Dr. Dreyfuss keeps at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get some air in here. Open the windows. Bud complies promptly -- pulls up the shades, opens the windows wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting the empty mug down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik -- Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran, slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran, I'm a doctor. I'm here because you took too many sleeping pills. Do you understand what I'm saying? (Fran mutters something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran, I'm Dr. Dreyfuss -- I'm here to help you. You took all those sleeping pills -- remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling groggily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Fran. And I'm a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Dreyfuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreyfuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get more coffee. Bud picks up the mug, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me again -- what's my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Dreyfuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took sleeping pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where you are, Fran?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around blankly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do. Now concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Bud is coming back with the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who this is? (Fran tries to focus)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baxter -- nineteenth floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister -- Miss -- such politeness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dr. Dreyfuss, discreetly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- we work in the same building -- and we try to keep it quiet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud, puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Bud throws Dr. Dreyfuss a look, as if to say that Fran's mind still wasn't functioning properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember? We were at the office party together --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes -- office party -- Miss Olsen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (to Dr. Dreyfuss; improvising rapidly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you we had a fight -- that's what it was about -- Miss Olsen -- you know that other girl you saw --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still trying to figure out Bud's presence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not important, Fran -- the main thing is that I got here in time -- and you're going to be all right -- (to Dr. Dreyfuss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- isn't she, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so tired --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- drink this. He forces her to swallow some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing the mug away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- just let me sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sleep. (shaking her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Fran -- open your eyes. (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get her walking. We've got to keep her awake for the next couple of hours. They lift her from the chair, and each draping one of her arms over his shoulder, they start to walk her up and dow the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urging Fran on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now walk, Fran. One, two, three, four -- one, two, three, four -- that's the idea -- left, right, left, right -- now we turn -- one, two, three, four -- At first, Fran's feet just drag along the floor between t But gradually, as Dr. Dreyfuss' voice continues droning hypnotically, she falls into the rhythm of it, repeating words after him and putting her weight on her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left, right, left, right -- walk, walk, walk -- one, two, three, four -- turn -- left, right, left, right -- now you got it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the bedroom window comes the first faint light of dawn. Fran has been put to bed by an exhausted Dr. Dreyfu She is in her slip, and Dreyfuss is just drawing the blan over her. Her eyes are closed, and she is moaning fitfull Watching from the doorway is Bud, in shirtsleeves now, we and disheveled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll sleep on and off for the next twenty-four hours. Of course, she'll have a dandy hangover when she wakes up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as long as she's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (massaging his calves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These cases are harder on the doctor than on the patient. I ought to charge you by the mile. They have now moved out into the living room, where the overhead light and the Christmas tree bulbs are still on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of that coffee left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He goes into the kitchen. Dr. Dreyfuss takes a small note with a fountain pen clipped to it out of his bag, sinks d on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you spell her last name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kubelik -- with two k's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her address? (no answer from Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does she live? Bud appears from the kitchen, stirring the coffee powder a cup of hot water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apprehensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know, Doc? You don't have to report this, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's regulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting the coffee down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't mean it, Doc -- it was an accident -- she had a little too much to drink and -- she didn't know what she was doing -- there was no suicide note or anything -- believe me, Doc, I'm not thinking about myself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping the hot coffee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that she's got a family -- and there's the people in the office -- look, Doc, can't you forget you're a doctor -- let's just say you're here as a neighbor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long look at Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as a doctor, I guess I can't prove it wasn't an accident. (closes notebook)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as your neighbor, I'd like to kick your keester clear around the block. (indicating coffee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I cool this off? He uncaps the bottle of Scotch, pours a large slug into h coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a big gulp of the spiked coffee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you did to that girl in there -- and don't tell me -- but it was bound to happen, the way you carry on. Live now, pay later. Diner's Club! (another swig)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you grow up, Baxter? Be a mensch! You know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mansch -- a human being! So you got off easy this time -- so you were lucky --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, wasn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing coffee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not out of the woods yet, Baxter -- because most of them try it again! (picks up bag, starts toward door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where I am if you need me. He walks out, closing the door after him. Bud dejectedly turns off the overhead light, kicks out the plug of the Christmas tree lights, trudges into the bedroom. Fran is fast asleep. Bud picks up her dress, gets a hange drapes the dress over it, hangs it from the door. An earl morning chill has invaded the room, and Bud switches an t electric blanket to keep Fran warm. Then he slumps into a chair beside the bed, looks at Fran compassionately. The light on the dial of the electric blanket glows in the grayish room. Bud just sits there, watching Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lieberman, followed by her dog, is climbing the stai to Bud's apartment, puffing asthmatically. She seems quit angry as she arrives at the door and rings the bell. Ther is no answer. She starts knocking impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baxter. Open up already! Finally the door opens a crack, and Bud peers out. He loo like a man who has slept in his clothes -- rumpled, blear eyed, unshaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Mrs. Lieberman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who did you think it was -- Kris Kringle? What was going on here last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that marching -- tramp, tramp, tramp -- you were having army maneuvers maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Lieberman -- and I'll never invite those people again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you get from renting to bachelors. All night I didn't sleep ten minutes -- and I'm sure you woke up Dr. Dreyfuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about Dr. Dreyfuss -- I happen to know he was out on a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, Mr. Baxter -- this is a respectable house, not a honky-tonky. (to the dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Oscar. Bud watches her start down the stairs with the dog, withd into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud closes the door, crosses toward the bedroom, looks inside. Fran is asleep under the electric blanket, breath evenly. He tries to shut the bedroom door, but it won't close completely because Fran's dress, on a hanger. is hooked over the top. He goes to the phone, picks it up, dials the operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operator, I want White Plains, New York -- Mr. J. D. Sheldrake -- (an added thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- make it person to person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decor is split-level Early American. There is a huge Christmas tree and a jumble of presents, open gift boxes, and discarded wrappings. Sheldrake and his two sons, TOMMY and JEFF JR., are squat on the floor, testing a Cape Canaveral set the kids got f Christmas. Sheldrake is in a brand new dressing gown, wit manufacturer's tag still dangling from it, and the boys a in pajamas and astronaut's helmets. As for the Cape Canav set, it is a miniature layout of block-houses, launching pads, and assorted space-missiles. Tommy has his finger o the button controlling one of the rockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7-6-5-4-3-2-1 -- let her rip! Tommy presses the button, and a spring sends the rocket toward the ceiling. Just then, the phone in the entrance hall starts ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. He hurries to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad -- why don't we put a fly in the nose cone and see if we can bring it back alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should send up two flies -- and see if they'll propagate in orbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if they'll what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Propagate -- you know, multiply -- baby flies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming back from the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for you, Dad. A Mr. Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Person to person. Sheldrake heads quickly for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeff Jr.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- help me round up some flies. In the entrance hall, Sheldrake picks up the phone, turns his back toward the living room, speaks in a low voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? -- yes -- what's on your mind, Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to disturb you, but something came up -- it's rather important -- and I think it would be a good idea if you could see me -- at the apartment -- as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not making sense, Baxter. What's this all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to tell you over the phone but that certain party -- you know who I mean -- I found her here last night -- she had taken an overdose of sleeping pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? From the stairway beyond him comes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Jeff? Who's on the phone? Sheldrake turns from the phone. Halfway down the stairs i Mrs. Sheldrake, in a quilted house-robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a nice recovery)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of our employees had an accident -- I don't know why they bother me with these things on Christmas Day. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Baxter -- just how serious is it? Out of the corner of his eye, he watches Mrs. Sheldrake c down the stairs, pass behind him on the way to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was touch and go there for a while -- but she's sleeping it off now. He glances through the half-open door toward the sleeping Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you'd like to be here when she wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible. (an apprehensive look toward the living room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to handle this situation yourself -- as a matter of fact, I'm counting on you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -- I understand. (taking Fran's letter out of his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She left a note -- you want me to open it and read it to you? (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was just a suggestion -- no, you don't have to worry about that, Mr. Sheldrake -- I kept your name out of it so there'll be no trouble, police-wise or newspaper- wise -- As Bud continues talking on the phone, Fran, in the bedro opens her eyes, looks around vaguely, trying to figure ou where she is. She sits up in bed, winces, holds her head her hands -- she has a fierce hangover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you see, the doctor, he's a friend of mine -- we were very lucky in that respect -- actually, he thinks she's my girl -- no, he just jumped to the conclusion -- around here, I'm known as quite a ladies' man -- In the bedroom Fran, becoming aware of Bud's voice, crawl out of bed and holding on to the furniture, moves unstead toward the living room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- of course, we're not out of the woods yet -- sometimes they try it again -- yes sir, I'll do my best -- it looks like it'll be a couple of days before she's fully recovered, and I may have a little problem with the landlady -- Behind him, Fran appears in the bedroom doorway, barefoot and in her slip. She leans groggily against the door post trying to focus on Bud and to concentrate on what he's sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- all right, Mr. Sheldrake, I'll keep her in my apartment as long as I can -- any sort of message you want me to give her? -- well, I'll think of something -- goodbye, Mr. Sheldrake. He hangs up the phone slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Bud turns around, sees her standing there on rubbery legs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik -- (hurries toward her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you shouldn't be out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know -- I had no idea this was your apartment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his arm around her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you. He leads her back into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so ashamed. Why didn't you just let me die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of talk is that? (he lowers her onto the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you got a little over- emotional -- but you're fine now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a groan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My head -- it feels like a big wad of chewing gum. What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling to her feet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my dress? I have to go home. Her knees buckle. Bud catches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in no condition to go anywhere -- except back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want me here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do. It's always nice to have company for Christmas. He tries to put her back to bed. Fran resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik, I'm stronger than you are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to go brush my teeth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- of course. I think there's a new toothbrush somewhere. He crosses to the bathroom, takes a plaid robe off the ho on the back of the door, hands it to Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- put this on. In the bathroom, he finds an unused toothbrush in a plast container. His eyes fall on his safety razor. With a glan toward the bedroom, he unscrews the razor, removes the blade, drops it in his shirt pocket. Then he empties the blades from the dispenser, puts those in his pocket. Now notices a bottle of iodine on the medicine shelf, stashes that in another pocket, just as Fran appears in the doorw wearing the robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing her the toothbrush)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. How about some breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I don't want anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fix you some coffee. He crosses the bedroom, heading for the kitchen, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- we're all out of coffee -- you had quite a lot of it last night -- He thinks for a moment, hurries toward the hall door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes out of his apartment, leaving the door half ope heads for the Dreyfuss apartment. He rings the bell, peer down over the banister to make sure Mrs. Lieberman isn't snooping around. Mrs. Dreyfuss opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dreyfuss, can I borrow some coffee -- and maybe an orange and a couple of eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggs he asks me for. Oranges. What you need is a good horse-whipping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From me the doctor has no secrets. Poor girl -- how could you do a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't really do anything -- honest -- I mean, you take a girl out a couple of times a week -- just for laughs -- and right away she thinks you're serious -- marriage-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big shot! For you, I wouldn't lift a finger -- but for her, I'll fix a little something to eat. She slams the door in his face, Bud starts back to his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran enters shakily from the bedroom, looks around for th phone, locates it, picks it up. As she starts dialing, Bu comes in from the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you calling, Miss Kubelik?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister -- she'll want to know what happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- let's talk this over first. (hurries up to her, takes the receiver away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what are you going to tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't figured it out, exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better figure it out -- exactly. Suppose she asks you why you didn't come home last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell her I spent the night with a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone from the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your friend's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss. (she is impressed with her own cleverness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong with your legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- it's my stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your stomach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had to pump it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hanging up the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik, I don't think you ought to call anybody -- not till that chewing gum is out of your head. (leads her into bedroom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they'll be worried about me -- my brother-in-law may be calling the police --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we have to be careful -- we don't want to involve anybody -- after all, Mr. Sheldrake is a married man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for reminding me. She pulls away from him, starts to get into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contritely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it that way -- I was just talking to him on the phone -- he's very concerned about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't give a damn about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're wrong. He told me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a liar. But that's not the worst part of it -- the worst part is -- I still love him. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be Mrs. Dreyfuss -- (starts into living room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- remember the doctor -- from last night -- that's his wife. He opens the hall door. Mrs. Dreyfuss brushes past him wi a tray full of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where is the victim? (Bud indicates the bedroom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max the Knife! She sweeps into the bedroom, Bud tagging along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nu, little lady, how are we feeling today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- kind of dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. The best thing for dizzy is a little noodle soup with chicken -- white meat -- and a glass tea. She sets the tray down on Fran's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm really not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead! Eat! Enjoy! She hands her the soup spoon, turns to Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have such a thing as a napkin, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have some paper towels --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatnik! Go to my kitchen -- third drawer, under the good silver, there is napkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Dreyfuss. He starts out with a worried backward glance toward the t Fran is just sitting there, the spoon in her hand, not touching the soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you waiting for -- a singing commercial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't eat. Mrs. Dreyfuss takes the spoon from her, starts to feed he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must eat -- and you must get healthy -- and you must forget him. Such a fine boy he seemed when he first moved in here -- clean and cut -- a regular Ivy Leaguer. Turns out he is King Farouk. Mit the drinking -- mit the cha cha -- mit the no napkins. A girl like you, for the rest of your life you want to cry in your noodle soup? Who needs it! You listen to me, you find yourself a nice, substantial man -- a widower maybe -- and settle down -- instead of nashing all those sleeping pills -- for what, for whom? -- for some Good Time Charlie? (sees Bud approaching with napkin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One napkin, coming up. (hands it to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish we had some champagne to wrap it around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mrs. Dreyfuss, you don't have to wait around. I'll wash the dishes and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wash 'em, you break 'em. I'll come back for them later. (to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he makes trouble, give me a yell. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't seem to like you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't mind. As a matter of fact, I'm sort of flattered -- that anybody should think a girl like you -- would do a thing like this -- over a guy like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at night table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Did you find something here -- an envelope -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've got it. (takes envelope out of back pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think we'd better destroy it? So it won't fall into the wrong hands -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it. Bud tears open the envelope, takes out Sheldrake's hundre dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing here but a hundred dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Will you see that Mr. Sheldrake gets it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He puts the money in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out tray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- take this, will you? Bud relieves her of the tray, sets it down.
