dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to move the television set in here? (Fran shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You play gin rummy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very good at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Let me get the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to entertain me. Bud opens the bureau drawer, takes out a deck of cards, a score pad, and a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing I'd like better -- you know togetherness. Guess what I did last Christmas. Had an early dinner at the automat, then went to the zoo, then I came home and cleaned up after Mr. Eichelberger -- he had a little eggnog party here. I'm way ahead this year. He pulls a chair up to the bed, starts to shuffle the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three across, spades double, high deals. (they cut)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight -- ten. (he starts to deal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pensively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to give it all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give what up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do people have to love people, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I know what you mean. (flips over down card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick a card. She does, and they start playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call it when somebody keeps getting smashed up in automobile accidents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bad insurance risk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me with men. I've been jinxed from the word go -- first time I was ever kissed was in a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was fifteen -- we used to go there to smoke. His name was George -- he threw me over for a drum majorette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin. He spreads his hand. Fran lays her cards down, and Bud ad them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-six and twenty-five -- that's sixty-one and two boxes. (enters score on pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have this talent for falling in love with the wrong guy in the wrong place at the wrong time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuffling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many guys were there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up four fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. The last one was manager of a finance company, back home in Pittsburgh -- they found a little shortage in his accounts, but he asked me to wait for him -- he'll be out in 1965.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing the deck toward her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she does, and he starts dealing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I came to New York and moved in with my sister and her husband -- he drives a cab. They sent me to secretarial school, and I applied for a job with Consolidated - but I flunked the typing test --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too slow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I can type up a storm, but I can't spell. So they gave me a pair of white gloves and stuck me in an elevator -- that's how I met Jeff -- (her eyes mist up, and she puts her cards down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I'm so fouled up. What am I going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better win a hand -- you're on a blitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he really upset when you told him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake? Oh, yes. Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he does love me -- only he doesn't have the nerve to tell his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that's the explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a thoughtful beat, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have that pad and the pencil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing her score pad and pencil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to write a letter to Mrs. Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As one woman to another -- I'm sure she'll understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik, I don't think that's such a good idea. He gently takes the pad and pencil away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing, you can't spell. And secondly -- if you did something like that -- you'd hate yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting back tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like myself very much anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick up your cards and let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. I got a terrific hand. Fran, her eyes drooping sleepily, picks up her cards, mak a discard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you want to throw that card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin. He removes the cards from her hand, starts to add them up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-two and twenty-five -- that's seventy-seven -- spades is double -- a hundred and fifty-four -- and four boxes -- you're blitzed in two games. He enters the score on the pad. As he starts to shuffle again, he notices that Fran has slid down on the pillow, that her eyes are closed -- she is asleep. Bud rises, adjusts the blanket over her. He stands there looking at her for a moment, runs his hand over his chin. Realizing he needs a shave, he crosses to the bathroom. In the bathroom, Bud washes his face, squirts some shavin cream into his hand, starts to apply it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Volkswagen draws up to the curb in front of the house. Kirkeby gets out on the street side, Sylvia squeezes hers out through the other door. Kirkeby raises the front hood the Volkswagen, reaches into the luggage compartment, tak out a cardboard bucket with a bottle of champagne on ice. Together, he and Sylvia start up the steps of the house, Sylvia already cha cha-ing in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bathroom, Bud has just finished lathering his face when the doorbell rings. He starts into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- all right, Mrs. Dreyfuss. He glances at the sleeping Fran, picks up the tray, carri it into the living room, pulling the bedroom door closed behind him. But it doesn't shut completely, because of Fran's dress hooked over the top. Bud crosses to the hall door, opens it. Outside are Kirke with the champagne bucket, and Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blocking the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I -- ? (to Sylvia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. He pushes his way into the apartment past Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing the door behind him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, Buddy- boy? I made a reservation for four o'clock, remember? He heads for the coffee table, sets the champagne down. B shoots a quick glance toward the bedroom door, gets rid o the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you can't stay here. Just take your champagne and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter, I don't want to pull rank on you -- but I told the lady it was all set -- you want to make a liar out of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to leave, Mr. Kirkeby, or do I have to throw you out? As Bud spins him around, Kirkeby notices the dress on the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy-boy, why didn't you say so? (indicating dress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got yourself a little playmate, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now will you get out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the door of Bud's apartment, Sylvia is cha cha-in impatiently. Up the stairs comes Dr. Dreyfuss, in his overcoat and carrying his medical bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knocking on the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come on, what are we waiting for? Open up, will you? She continues cha-cha-ing. Dr. Dreyfuss has unlocked the door to his apartment, and is watching Sylvia, appalled b the fact that Baxter seems to be at it again. He starts inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred --  ! He shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knocking on Baxter's door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's holding things up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirkeby looks toward the door in response to Sylvia's knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, why don't we have ourselves a party -- the four of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He forces Kirkeby toward the hall door. Kirkeby, glancing past him through the partly-open door of the bedroom, catches sight of Fran asleep in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning smugly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't blame you. So you hit the jackpot, eh kid -- I mean, Kubelik-wise? (Bud opens the door, gestures him out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I won't say a word to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirkeby comes backing out the door of Bud's apartment, mi the champagne bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with it, Buddy-boy! (Bud shuts the door on him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little mixup in signals. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leading her toward stairs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your mother doing this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's home -- stuffing a turkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we send her to a movie -- like Ben-Hur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. But what are we going to do about grandma and Uncle Herman and Aunt Sophie and my two nieces --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes into the bedroom. As he heads for the bathroom, Fran stirs slightly, opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just somebody delivering a bottle of champagne. Like some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind opening the window? She turns off the electric blanket as Bud crosses to the window, pushes it up. Then a thought strikes him, and he looks at Fran suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't go getting any ideas, Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want some fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only one story down -- the best you can do is break a leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they'll shoot me -- like a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Miss Kubelik, you got to promise me you won't do anything foolish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I ever fall in love with somebody nice like you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well -- that's the way it crumbles, cookie-wise. Go to sleep. Fran closes her eyes. Bud returns to the bathroom, picks his razor, starts to shave. But something seems to be wro with the razor -- and unscrewing it, he realizes that the is no blade. Sheepishly, he takes out the blade he hid in his shirt pocket, inserts it in his razor, screws it shut Then he resumes shaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the morning after Christmas, and Miss Olsen and the other girls are just settling down to work. Sheldrake, in hat and coat, approaches from the elevators, comes throug the glass doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Olsen, will you come into my office, please? He strides into the inner office. Miss Olsen picks up her stenographic pad, follows him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheldrake is removing his hat and coat as Miss Olsen come in, shuts the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a nice Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely. You were a big help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for giving that little pep talk to Miss Kubelik at the office party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping her business-like mask)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Jeff. You know I could never hold my liquor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought you could hold your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet it won't. I'll arrange for you to get a month's severance pay -- (she looks at him, uncomprehending)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Miss Olsen. I'm letting you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let me go four years ago, Jeff. Only you were cruel enough to make me sit out there and watch the new models pass by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate it if you'd be out of here as soon as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (formal again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Sheldrake. She turns and walks out of the office, shutting the door. Sheldrake looks after her for a moment, then goes to his desk, picks up the phone, dials the operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Sheldrake. I'd like Mr. Baxter's home telephone number -- that's C.C. Baxter, in Ordinary Premium Accounting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Olsen has put on her coat, and is going through her desk drawers, cleaning out her personal belongings -- nai polish, emery boards, an extra pair of glasses, etc. As s stows them away in her handbag, one of the buttons on the telephone lights up. Miss Olsen hesitates for a second, t with a quick look around, she pushes the button down, carefully picks up the receiver, listens in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheldrake is dialing the last two digits of a telephone number. After a moment, someone answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Baxter? Jeff Sheldrake. Can you talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud, wearing slacks, a shirt open at the neck, and a card sweater, is at the phone. A pillow and a blanket on the living room couch indicate where he spent the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's in the shower -- she's coming along fine, considering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Is there anything you need -- money -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Mr. Sheldrake. As a matter of fact, I've got some money for you -- a hundred dollars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if there's anything I can do for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me? I don't think so. But I was hoping maybe you could do something for her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what? Put yourself in my place, Baxter -- how can I help her -- my hands are tied --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran now appears in the bedroom, wearing the plaid robe, toweling her damp hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least you can talk to her -- let me put her on -- and please be gentle -- He puts the receiver down, crosses toward the bedroom doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a call for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mr. Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should. I have to run down to the grocery anyway -- all that's left around here is one frozen pizza -- (takes raincoat and old hat from hanger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back -- okay? Fran nods, watches him go out. Then she glances toward th phone, which is off the hook. Reluctantly she advances toward it, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jeff. (a long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran, why did you do it? It's so childish -- and it never solves anything -- I ought to be very angry with you, scaring me like that -- but let's forget the whole thing -- pretend it never happened -- what do you say, Fran? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Olsen, glued to the phone, is listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there, Fran?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm not here -- because the whole thing never happened -- I never took those pills -- I never loved you -- we never even met -- isn't that the way you want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go again -- you know I didn't mean it that way, Fran. Just get well -- do what the nurse tells you -- I mean Baxter -- and I'll see you as soon as I can. Bye, Fran. (he hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Olsen hangs up the phone, sits there for a moment, weighing what she has overheard. Then she makes a decisio picks up the phone again, dials a number. As she waits fo an answer, she glances toward Sheldrake's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Sheldrake? This is Miss Olsen -- fine, thank you -- Mrs. Sheldrake, I was wondering if we could have lunch together? -- well, I don't know how important it is, but I think you might find it educational -- it concerns your husband -- all right, one o'clock, at Longchamp's, Madison and 59th. She looks up as the door to the inner office opens and Sheldrake comes out. He stops when he sees that Miss Olse is still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hanging up phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'm on my way. (she rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just making a personal call. She opens her handbag, takes out a coin, puts it down on desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a dime. She marches out through the glass doors toward the elevat as Sheldrake stands there, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes down the street, carrying a large brown paper b overflowing with groceries. He goes up the steps of the house and through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bud starts up the stairs, with the groceries, Mrs. Lieberman comes hurrying down toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathlessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Baxter -- I'm glad you're here -- I was just going to get the passkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I smelled gas coming from your apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas? He races up the stairs two at a time, fumbling franticall for his key. Reaching the door of his apartment, he unloc it, dashes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes bursting through the door. The living room is empty, and the bedclothes have been removed from the couc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik! He dumps the bag of groceries on a table, rushes into the kitchen. The burner has been turned on under the kettle, there is no flame, and gas is hissing from the vents. Bud snaps it off, starts out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik! Meanwhile Fran has appeared from the bathroom, and is approaching the bedroom door. She is still in her robe, a is holding a double sock-stretcher with one of Bud's sock on it. Bud, rounding the corner from the kitchen at full speed, collides with Fran in the bedroom doorway. He grab her arms with obvious relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (sniffs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that funny smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas. (indicating kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you turn it on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was boiling some water to get the coffee stains out of my dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned it on -- but you didn't light it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this house, you're supposed to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Bud starts to take off his hat and coat, notices the sock stretcher in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was washing my stockings, so I decided I might as well do your socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very curious -- I could only find three and a half pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, things are a little disorganized around here. He carries the bag of groceries into the kitchen, Fran trailing after him. During the following, he removes the contents of the bag -- bread, eggs, bacon, spaghetti, gro round, frankfurters, and assorted canned goods -- sets th out on the drainboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say. What's a tennis racquet doing in the kitchen? She produces the racquet from behind the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennis racquet? Oh, I remember -- I was cooking myself an Italian dinner. (Fran looks at him oddly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used it to strain the spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking it over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I'm a pretty good cook -- but I'm a lousy housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are, (indicating the living room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was straightening up the couch, you know what I found? Six hairpins, a lipstick, a pair of false eyelashes, and a swizzle stick from the Stork Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that I'm the kind of guy who can't say no -- I don't mean to girls -- I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to someone like Mr. Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know so. He's a taker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people take, some people get took -- and they know they're getting took -- and there's nothing they can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say that -- (trying to change the subject)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like to have for diner? There's onion soup and canned asparagus --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really ought to be getting home. My family will be flipping by now. She starts into the living room. Bud follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave yet. The doctor says it takes forty-eight hours to get the stuff out of your system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how long it takes to get someone you're stuck on out of your system? If they'd only invent some kind of a pump for that -- She sits on the arm of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here -- (with cocked finger, he points to his temple, mouth and chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you know where I finally shot myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating kneecap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the knee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you just making that up to make me feel better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. Here's the fruit cake. (shows it to her under Christmas tree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want to see my knee? (starts to raise pant-leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. The fellows in the office may get the wrong idea how I found out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let 'em. Look, I'm going to cook dinner for us. We'll have the fruit cake for dessert. You just sit there and rest. You've done enough for one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, nurse. Bud starts happily into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is mid-afternoon, and traffic is light. A Yellow Cab h pulled up in front of the entrance, and the driver, a stockily-built young man in a leather jacket and cap, get out and comes through the revolving doors into the lobby. His name is KARL MATUSCHKA, and he is Fran's brother-in-l As he cases the elevators, the starter comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for one of the elevator girls -- Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I. She didn't report this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't. Where can I get some information -- who's in charge here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That comes under General Office Administration. See Mr. Dobisch, twenty-first floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. He steps into an elevator, the doors of which are just closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dobisch is sitting behind his desk, lighting a cigar. Kirkeby, who has dropped in for a little visit, is perche on the edge of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so yesterday afternoon I take Sylvia up to the apartment, and guess who he's got stashed away in the bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. Buddy-boy and Kubelik having themselves a little toot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toot? It's more like a lost weekend. Neither of them showed up for work today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gripes me is the two of them were guzzling my champagne while Sylvia and I wound up at the Guggenheim Museum. The glass door opens and Matuschka comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dobisch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Karl Matuschka -- my sister-in-law, she runs one of the elevators here -- Fran Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exchanging a glance with Dobisch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Kubelik?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. There may be a lot of employees here -- but we're one big happy family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she lives with us -- and my wife, she's getting a little nervous -- on account of Fran hasn't been home for two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another look at Dobisch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, we was wondering if somebody in the office would know what happened to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (to Kirkeby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, Al? Can we help the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pregnant pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? We don't owe Buddy-boy anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What's Buddy-boy done for us lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Buddy-boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy-boy is bending over a hot stove, preparing an Itali dinner. He takes a saucepan of spaghetti off the fire, an picking up the tennis racquet with the other hand, pours spaghetti on top of the racquet strings. Then he turns on the faucet, runs water over the spaghetti. With the combi technique of Brillat-Savarin and Pancho Gonzales, he gent agitates the racquet, letting the water drain off the spaghetti. As he works, he hums a theme from Tschaikowsky Capriccio Italien. Fran walks in, still in her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we dressing for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- just come as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you're pretty good with that racquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to see my backhand. (dumping spaghetti into platter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wait till I serve the meatballs. (demonstrates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I light the candles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a must -- gracious-living-wise. As Fran starts into the living room, Bud begins to ladle meat sauce onto the spaghetti, humming operatically. In the living room, the small table has been set for two, and prominent on it is the champagne bottle that Mr. Kirk left behind, still in its cardboard bucket, but freshly i As Fran lights the candles, she notices the napkins on th table, peels a price-tag off the corner of one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you bought some napkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might as well go all the way. He carries the platter of spaghetti and meat sauce in fro the kitchen, sets it on the table, sprinkles some cheese it. Then he crosses to the coffee table, where a full martini pitcher stands in readiness, fills a couple of glasses. Fran seats herself at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I used to live like Robinson Crusoe -- shipwrecked among eight million people. Then one day I saw a footprint in the sand -- and there you were -- (hands her martini)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a wonderful thing -- dinner for two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You usually eat alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Sometimes I have dinner with Ed Sullivan, sometimes with Dinah Shore or Perry Como -- the other night I had dinner with Mae West -- of course, she was much younger then. (toasting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what we're going to do after dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dishes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to if you don't want to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to finish that gin game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I want you to keep a clear head. The door bell rings. Carrying his martini glass, Bud cros to the door, starts to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't want to take advantage of you -- the way I did yesterday in bed. By now the door is open, and Bud is speaking to Fran over his shoulder. He turns, finds himself face to face with K Matuschka, who is standing grimly in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Matuschka shoves him roughly aside, strides past him towa Fran, who has risen to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you, Fran -- did you forget where you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my brother-in-law, Karl Matuschka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (friendly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Matuschka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing Bud away; to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, get your clothes on. I got the cab downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute. I know what you're thinking -- but it's not as bad as it looks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving him away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's none of my business what you do, Fran -- you're over twenty- one -- but your sister happens to think you're a lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we were going to do is eat and wash the dishes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Buddy-boy -- if there wasn't a lady present, I'd clobber you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (separating them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Karl -- I'll get dressed. She exits into the bedroom, removing her dress from the door, and closing it. Matuschka leans against the wall beside the hall door, eyeing Bud truculently. Bud raises finger to remonstrate with him -- then breaks into a nerv ingratiating smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care for a martini? Champagne? (Matuschka continues glaring at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a little spaghetti with meat sauce? Made it myself. (Matuschka just scowls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister-in-law sure is terrific -- (realizes his mistake; switching abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be murder driving a cab in New York -- I mean, with all that cross-town traffic -- He gestures with the martini glass, spilling the contents over his shirtfront. Through the partly open hall door, D Dreyfuss sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Baxter. He steps into the apartment, passing Matuschka without seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the patient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm fine, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you -- Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with Miss Kubelik?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is Mr. Matuschka -- he's Miss Kubelik's -- he's got a cab downstairs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dreyfuss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran been sick or something? Dr. Dreyfuss looks at Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- just had a little accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dreyfuss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he mean, accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, these things happen all the time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What things? (grabbing Dreyfuss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what kind of doctor are you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, not that kind. He just gave her a shot and pumped her stomach out -- Behind them, the bedroom door has opened, and Fran comes out, wearing her coat over her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I took some sleeping pills. But I'm all right now -- so let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you take sleeping pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (promptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On account of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whirling on him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else? Matuschka lashes out with a left to Bud's jaw, and while is off balance, catches him with a right to the eye. Bud falls back against the Christmas tree, which topples with crash. Fran pulls Matuschka away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, Karl. She kneels beside Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fool -- you damn fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Baxter. She kisses him on the cheek, rises, starts toward the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, doctor. She follows Matuschka out. Bud looks after her, starry-ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to gloat, but just between us, you had that coming to you. (tilts Bud's chin up, examines his eye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, tch, tch. Are you going to have a shiner tomorrow. Let me get my bag. (he starts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother, Doc. It doesn't hurt a bit. He is on Cloud Nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is coming from the elevators toward his office. He is wearing his chesterfield, bowler, and a pair of dark glas He opens the office door, starts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud crosses directly to the phone, removes his glasses revealing a swollen left eye. He dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake's office? This is C.C. Baxter. Would you please tell Mr. Sheldrake I'd like to come up and see him? It's rather important. Will you call me back, please? He hangs up, takes off his hat and coat, deposits them on the clothes- tree. Then he paces around the office, rehearsing a speech out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you. All your troubles are over. I'm going to take Miss Kubelik off your hands. (nods to himself with satisfaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plain fact is, Mr. Sheldrake, that I love her. I haven't told her yet, but I thought you should be the first to know. After all, you don't really want her, and I do, and although it may sound presumptuous, she needs somebody like me. So I think it would be the thing all around -- (the phone rings and he picks it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- solution-wise. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? I'll be right up. He hangs up, crosses to the door, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you -- Putting on his dark glasses, he heads for the elevators, still talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirkeby and Dobisch are just stepping out of an elevator when Bud approaches. They grin smugly when they see that is wearing dark glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Buddy-boy. What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit by a swinging door? Or maybe a Yellow Cab? Bud pays no attention, walks right past them into the elevator, still muttering to himself. The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they move away from the elevators)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy really must've belted him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's punchy. Talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven. Bud steps out. As he heads for Sheldrake's office, he continues rehearsing his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Mr. Sheldrake, those two days she spent in the apartment -- it made me realize how lonely I'd been before. But thanks to you, I'm in a financial position to marry her -- if I can ever square things with her family. He opens the door to Sheldrake's anteroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheldrake is pacing in front of his desk. A couple of suitcases are standing in a corner of the room. The inter buzzes, and Sheldrake presses the lever down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baxter is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him in. A beat, then the door opens, and Bud marches in determine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've got good news for you, Baxter. All your troubles are over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting to the echo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how worried you were about Miss Kubelik -- well, stop worrying -- I'm going to take her off your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to take her off my hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (indicating suitcases)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've moved out of my house -- I'm going to be staying in town, at the Athletic Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you must know -- I fired my secretary, my secretary got to my wife, and my wife fired me. Ain't that a kick in the head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what was your news, Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering with difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about Miss Kubelik -- she's all right again -- so she went back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell. And don't think I've forgotten what you did for me. (opens door to adjoining office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Baxter. Bud advances slowly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a slightly smaller and less lavish edition of Sheld s office. Sheldrake ushers Bud through the door, points t the chair behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. Try it on for size. Bud obeys like an automaton, lowers himself into the chai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like? (indicating office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My assistant, Roy Thompson, has been shifted to the Denver office, and you're taking his place. (no reaction from Bud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Baxter? You don't seem very excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's just that so many things have been happening so fast -- I'm very pleased -- especially for Miss Kubelik. Now that I've gotten to know her better, I think she's the kind of girl that definitely ought to be married to somebody --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure, sure. But first the property settlement has to be worked out -- then it takes six weeks in Reno -- meanwhile, I'm going to enjoy being a bachelor for a while. (starts back toward his own office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, you can now have lunch in the executive dining room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He removes his dark glasses reflectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just one of the privileges that goes with this job. You also get a nice little expense account, the use of the executive washroom -- (breaks off, peers at Bud's face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what happened to you, Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got kicked in the head, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? With a shrug, he exits into his own office, closing the d behind him. Bud sits there, unconsciously bending the glasses in his hand until they suddenly snap in two. Bud glances down at the two broken halves, as though surprise by his own violence, tosses them on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are close on the building directory. Listed under PERSONNEL is J.D. SHELDRAKE, Director, and just below tha hand is inserting the name C.C. BAXTER in the slot marked Director. The lettering is complete except for the final Camera pulls back to reveal the sign painter we saw earli working on the directory. Watching him is Bud. He is wear his chesterfield and bowler, and still has a slight welt under his left eye. It is after six o'clock, and there is very little activity in the lobby. Fran, wearing her coat over street clothes, approaches fr the direction of the elevators, stops when she sees Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Baxter. Bud turns to her in surprise, removes his bowler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Kubelik. How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. How's your eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. There is a moment of constraint between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's everything at the apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's changed. You know, we never finished that gin game --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you heard about Mr. Sheldrake --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, leaving his wife? Yeah. I'm very happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought he'd do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you all along. You see, you were wrong about Mr. Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For that matter, you were wrong about me, too. What you said about those who take and those who get took? Well, Mr. Sheldrake wasn't using me -- I was using him. See? (indicating his name on directory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last month I was at desk 861 on the nineteenth floor -- now I'm on the twenty-seventh floor, paneled office, three windows -- so it all worked out fine -- we're both getting what we want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (looks at her watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walking to the subway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. (fumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- well, to tell you the truth -- (glancing around lobby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I have this heavy date for tonight -- He points off toward the newsstand. Standing there is a tall, attractive brunette, obviously waiting for someone. Fran looks off in the indicated direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you meeting Mr. Sheldrake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You know how people talk. So I decided it would be better if we didn't see each other till everything is settled, divorce-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Miss Kubelik. Fran walks toward the revolving doors. Bud watches her fo moment, then strides briskly across the lobby toward the newsstand. He goes right past the waiting brunette, stops front of a rack of pocket books, examines the merchandise man now comes out of a phone booth, joins the waiting brunette, and they go off together. Bud picks out a coupl of paperbacks, pays the clerk behind the counter. Stuffin book into each coat pocket, he moves slowly toward the revolving doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheldrake is swiveled around sideways behind his desk, wi a bootblack kneeling in front of him, shining his shoes. Reaching for the intercom, Sheldrake presses down one of levers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter -- would you mind stepping in her for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Sheldrake. The bootblack finishes the second shoe with a flourish, gathers up his equipment. Sheldrake tosses him a half dol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much obliged. He exits into the anteroom as the door of the adjoining office opens and Bud comes in, carrying several charts. There is no trace left of his black eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting charts on desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the breakdown of figures on personnel turnover. Thirty-seven percent of our female employees leave to get married, twenty-two percent quit because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're working too hard, Baxter. It's New Year's Eve -- relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you'll be on the town tonight -- celebrating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too. I'm taking Miss Kubelik out -- I finally talked her into it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing is I'm staying at the Athletic Club -- and it's strictly stag so if you don't mind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that other key to your apartment -- well, when we had that little scare about Miss Kubelik, I thought I'd better get rid of it quick -- so I threw it out the window of the commuter train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'll have to borrow your key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Sheldrake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to bring anybody up to my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not just bringing anybody -- I'm bringing Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially not Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No key!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter, I picked you for my team because I thought you were a bright young man. You realize what you're doing? Not to me -- but to yourself. Normally it takes years to work your way up to the twenty-seventh floor -- but it takes only thirty seconds to be out on the street again. You dig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's it going to be? Without taking his eyes off Sheldrake, Bud reaches into h pocket, fishes out a key, drops it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're being bright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. He turns abruptly, starts back into his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes in, shutting the door behind him, stands rooted the spot for a moment. Then he takes some pencils out of breast pocket and drops them into a container on the desk closes his account book, slams a couple of open file draw shut. As he crosses to the clothes closet, the connecting door opens and Sheldrake comes in, key in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Baxter -- you gave me the wrong key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding it out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is the key to the executive washroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Mr. Sheldrake. I won't be needing it -- because I'm all washed up around here. He has taken his chesterfield and bowler out of the close and is putting the coat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's gotten into you, Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just following doctor's orders. I've decided to become a mensch. You know what that means? A human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold on, Baxter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it. The old payola won't work any more. Goodbye, Mr. Sheldrake. He opens the door to the anteroom, starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud comes out of his office, carrying his bowler, strides past the secretaries and through the glass doors to the foyer. An elevator is just unloading, and beside it a handyman is cleaning out one of the cigarette receptacles Bud crosses to the elevator, and as he passes the handyma he jams his bowler on the man's head -- surrendering his crown, so to speak. The elevator doors close. The handyma straightens up, looks around in bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud is in the process of packing. In the middle of the living room are several large cardboard cartons filled wi his possessions. The art posters are off the walls, the bric-a-brac has been removed from the shelves, and Bud is stowing away the last of his books and records. He crosse to the fireplace, opens one of the drawers in the cabinet above it, takes out a forty-five automatic. He holds the in the palm of his hand, studies it appraisingly. The doorbell rings. Bud snaps out of his reverie, drops t gun into one of the cartons, goes to the door and opens i Standing outside is Dr. Dreyfuss, with a plastic ice buck in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Baxter -- we're having a little party and we ran out of ice -- so I was wondering --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping inside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're alone on New Year's Eve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have things to do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noticing cartons)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this -- you packing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I'm giving up the apartment. He goes into the kitchen, opens the refrigerator, starts pry out the ice-cube trays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you moving to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. All I know is I got to get out of this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to lose you, Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, you mean my body. Don't worry, Doc -- it'll go to the University -- I'll put it in writing -- He dumps the ice-cubes, still in their trays, into the bucket Dr. Dreyfuss is holding. Then he pulls Kirkeby's unopened bottle of champagne out of the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you use a bottle of champagne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booze we don't need. Why don't you join us, Baxter? We got two brain surgeons, an ear, nose and throat specialist, a proctologist, and three nurses from Bellevue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks -- I don't feel like it. Look, Doc -- in case I don't see you again -- how much do I owe you for taking care of that girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it -- I didn't do it as a doctor -- I did it as a neighbor. (stopping in doorway)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, whatever happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (airily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me with girls. Easy come, easy go. Goodbye, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year. Bud closes the door, returns to the kitchen, brings out a box of glassware and the tennis racquet. As he starts to deposit the racquet in a carton, he notices a strand of spaghetti clinging to the strings. He removes it gently, stands there twirling the limp spaghetti absently around finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is five minutes before midnight, New Year's Eve. Sitti alone in the last booth is Fran, a paper hat on her head, pensive look on her face. There are two champagne glasses the table, and the usual noisemakers, but the chair oppos her is empty. Above the general hubbub, the Chinese piani can be heard playing. After a moment, Fran glances off. Threading his way through the merrymakers crowding the ba and overflowing from the booths is Sheldrake. He is in dinner clothes, topped by a paper hat. Reaching the last booth, he drops into the chair facing Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All set for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rented a car -- it's going to be here at one o'clock -- we're driving to Atlantic City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atlantic City?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's a drag -- but you can't find a hotel room in town -- not on New Year's Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long look at Sheldrake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't plan it this way, Fran -- actually, it's all Baxter's fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baxter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't give me the key to the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just walked out on me -- quit -- threw that big fat job right in my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a faint smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little punk -- after all I did for him! He said I couldn't bring anybody to his apartment -- especially not Miss Kubelik. What's he got against you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a faraway look in her eye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd spell it out for you -- only I can't spell. The piano player is consulting the watch on his upraised left arm. He drops the arm in a signal, and the lights go out. At the same time, he strikes up AULD LANG SYNE. All over the dimly lit room, couples get to their feet, embracing and joining in the song. In the last booth, Sheldrake leans across the table, kiss Fran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, Fran. Fran's expression is preoccupied. Sheldrake faces in the direction of the pianist, and holding his glass aloft, si along with the others. As AULD LANG SYNE comes to an end, the place explodes noisily -- there is a din of horns, ratchets, and shouted greetings. The lights come up again. In the last booth, Sheldrake turns back toward Fran -- bu she is no longer there. Her paper hat lies abandoned on h vacated chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran -- (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where are you, Fran? He rises, cranes his neck, trying to spot her in the crow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran, a coat thrown over the dress she was wearing at the Rickshaw, comes down the street almost at a run. There is happy, expectant look on her face. She hurries up the ste of the house and through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran mounts the stairs eagerly. As she reaches the landin and heads for Bud's apartment, there is a loud, sharp rep from inside. Fran freezes momentarily, then rushes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baxter! (pounding on door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baxter! Mr. Baxter! The door opens and there stands Bud, the bottle of champa he has just uncorked still foaming over in his hand. He stares at Fran unbelievingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sagging with relief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? How's your knee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran comes in and Bud shuts the door. The room is the sam as we left it, except for an empty champagne glass standi on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get another glass. He goes to one of the cartons, takes out a champagne glas wrapped in newspaper, starts to unwrap it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows? Another neighborhood -- another town -- another job -- I'm on my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny -- so am I. (Bud, pouring champagne, looks up at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do with the cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating carton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In there. Fran takes the deck of cards and the gin rummy score pad of the carton, settles herself on the couch, starts to shuffle the cards expertly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Mr. Sheldrake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to send him a fruit cake every Christmas. Bud sinks down happily on the couch, and Fran holds out t deck to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut. Bud cuts a card, but doesn't look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Miss Kubelik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting a card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven -- (looking at Bud's card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- queen. She hands the deck to Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said, Miss Kubelik? I absolutely adore you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and deal! Bud begins to deal, never taking his eyes off her. Fran removes her coat, starts picking up her cards and arrangi them. Bud, a look of pure joy on his face, deals -- and deals -- and keeps dealing. And that's about it. Story-wise.
